questions.text: The following image is of a case of atopic eczema. The infraorbital folds seen are called:
The phenomenon shown in the image given below is due to?

choices.text: Synthesis of stable troponin C molecules

questions.solution:
Treppe phenomenon shown in the image is due to Increased availability of intracellular calcium.

Treppe phenomenon:

  • Changes in muscle strength at the onset of muscle contraction due to repeated stimuliis known as staircase effect or treppe phenomenon.
  • When a muscle begins to contract after a long period of rest, its initial strength of contraction may be as little as one half its strength 10 to 50 muscle twitches later.
  • That is, the strength of contraction increases to a plateau, a phenomenon called the staircase effect, or treppe.
  • It is believed to be caused primarily by increasing calcium ions in the cytosol because of the release of more and more ions from the sarcoplasmic reticulum with each successive muscle action potential `and failure of the sarcoplasm to recapture the ions immediately.

questions.text: Physician-assisted suicide amounts to:
questions.solution:
• Voluntary active euthanasia is most often referred to as physician-assisted suicide (PAS).
  • PAS is physician providing medications or other interventions to a patient with understanding that the patient intends to use them to commit suicide.
  • Euthanasia is also called mercy killing and is usually brought about by a physician.
  • Types of euthanasia:
    • Voluntary euthanasia: The end of a patient’s life is induced at the request or will of the patient.
    • Involuntary euthanasia: The end of a patient’s life is induced against the will of the patient.
    • Non-voluntary euthanasia: This is euthanasia conducted when the patient’s consent is unavailable like child euthanasia.
    • Active euthanasia: This involves intentionally administering medications or other interventions to cause the patient’s death.
    • Passive euthanasia: This involves withholding or withdrawing life-sustaining medical treatments from the patient to let him or her die.

questions.text: Non union is a complication of
questions.solution:
Non-union is a complication of fracture through the waist of scaphoid.

The blood supply of the scaphoid diminishes proximally. This accounts for the fact that 1 percent of distal third fractures, 20 percent of middle third fractures and 40 percent of proximal fractures result in non-union or avascular necrosis of the proximal fragment.

In non-union, bone grafting should be attempted especially in the younger and more vigorous type of patient, because this probably reduces the chance of later symptomatic osteoarthritis.

If these techniques fail to achieve union then the options are vascularized bone graft, scaphoidectomy with proximal-to-distal-row (four-corner) fusion, proximal row carpectomy or radio-carpal arthrodesis.

questions.text: The given image shows the strength of muscle contraction with successive stimulation. What is the cause of the phenomenon shown?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the staircase effect or the Treppe phenomenon and occurs because of increased intracellular calcium.

When a muscle begins to contract after a long period of rest, the strength of muscle contraction during each twitch increases successively with each stimulus. After this, the strength of contraction in each twitch reaches a plateau. This phenomenon is called the staircase effect or the Treppe phenomenon. It is caused primarily by the increasing calcium ions in the cytosol. Each successive muscle contraction causes more and more calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, and these ions cannot be recaptured back immediately.

As the frequency of contractions further increases, a new contraction begins to occur before the previous one is over. Thus, the second contraction is added to the first one and the strength of the contraction increases. As this phenomenon progresses, the frequency reaches a critical level and the contractions become so rapid that they fuse together into a smooth and continuous contraction. This phenomenon is known as frequency summation and tetanization (options B and C).

 

Length-tension relationship (option A) refers to the relationship between the length of the muscle fiber and the active tension that it develops. As the length of the muscle is increased, there is an increase in the active tension which develops in a muscle due to more overlapping between the actin filaments and the myosin cross-bridges. However, this increase in tension only occurs till a limit. The optimum length at which the maximum tension develops is 2.0 to 2.2 μm of length.

questions.text: Which of the following growth factors is chemotactic for neutrophils, macrophages, fibroblasts, and smooth muscle cells in inflammation and tissue injury?
questions.solution:
PDGF is chemotactic for neutrophils, macrophages, fibroblasts, and smooth muscle cells and promotes the recruitment of the cells into areas of inflammation and tissue injury.

Platelet-Derived Growth Factor.

  • Three isoforms of PDGF (AA, AB, and BB) are constitutively active; PDGF-CC and PDGF-DD.
  • PDGF is stored in platelet granules and is released on platelet activation.
  • It is also produced by many other cells, including activated macrophages, endothelium, smooth muscle cells, and a variety of tumors.
  • All PDGF isoforms exert their effects by binding to two cell surface receptors (PDGFR α and β), both having intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity.
  • PDGF induces fibroblast, endothelial, and smooth muscle cell proliferation and matrix synthesis, and is chemotactic for these cells.

Growth Factors Involved in Regeneration and Repair

Growth Factor Sources Functions
Epidermal growth factor (EGF) Activated macrophages, salivary glands,keratinocytes, and many other cells Mitogenic for keratinocytes and fibroblasts; stimulates keratinocytemigration; stimulates formation of granulation tissue
Transforming growth factor-α (TGF-α) Activated macrophages, keratinocytes, many other cell types. Stimulates proliferation of hepatocytes and many other epithelialcells
Hepatocyte growth factor (HGF) (scatter factor) Fibroblasts, stromal cells in the liver, endothelial cells Enhances proliferation of hepatocytes and other epithelial cells;increases cell motility
Vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) Mesenchymal cells Stimulates proliferation of endothelial cells; increases vascularpermeability
Platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF) Platelets, macrophages, endothelial cells,smooth muscle cells, keratinocytes Chemotactic for neutrophils, macrophages, fibroblasts, and smoothmuscle cells; activates and stimulates proliferation of fibroblasts,endothelial, and other cells; stimulates ECM protein synthesis
Fibroblast growth factors (FGFs), including acidic (FGF-1) and basic (FGF-2) Macrophages, mast cells, endothelial cells,many other cell types  Chemotactic and mitogenic for fibroblasts; stimulates angiogenesisand ECM protein synthesis
Transforming growth factor-β (TGF-β) Platelets, T lymphocytes, macrophages, endothelial cells, keratinocytes, smooth muscle cells, fibroblasts Chemotactic for leukocytes and fibroblasts; stimulates ECM proteinsynthesis; suppresses acute inflammation

questions.solution:

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with facial rashes, as shown below. The lesions have progressed slowly over the past several months and are asymptomatic but cosmetically concerning. The rash is not triggered by sun exposure. She also reports intermittent cough and mild shortness of breath. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation and the facial rash (suggestive of lupus pernio) suggest a diagnosis of chronic sarcoidosis. 

Lupus pernio is a chronic cutaneous manifestation of sarcoidosis, characterized by violaceous, indurated plaques or nodules that primarily affect the nose, cheeks, lips, and ears. Unlike the malar rash of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), which is erythematous and photosensitive, lupus pernio is often chronic and does not resolve spontaneously. The lesions are typically asymptomatic but may cause cosmetic concerns and, in severe cases, lead to tissue damage or deformity.

Lupus pernio is strongly associated with systemic sarcoidosis, particularly pulmonary involvement. Many patients present with underlying respiratory symptoms, such as cough, dyspnea, and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, on imaging. The condition is also linked to chronic sarcoidosis, which has extrapulmonary manifestations, including involvement of the upper respiratory tract, eyes, and bones. A biopsy of affected skin typically reveals non-caseating granulomas, which confirm the diagnosis.

Treatment of lupus pernio includes systemic corticosteroids. In refractory cases, immunosuppressive agents such as methotrexate, hydroxychloroquine, or tumor necrosis factor (TNF)-alpha inhibitors may be required.

questions.text: A family consists of 2 immunized parents and 6 children susceptible to measles. There occurs a primary case of measles and 3 secondary cases within a short period of time. Secondary attack rate is:
questions.solution:
• The secondary attack rate here is 60%.
  • Secondary attack rate (SAR) = (Number of exposed or susceptible persons developing the disease within the incubation period x 100) / (Total number of close or exposed contacts that are susceptible).
  • In this scenario, total susceptible children are 6 out of which one is the primary case and 3 children got measles.
  • Thus SAR = 3 x100 / 5 = 60%.
  • The primary case is not included in the denominator or numerator in SAR.

questions.solution:

This space is divided into two compartments by the mylohyoid muscle:

  2. Submaxillary and submental compartment (below the mylohyoid).

The two compartments are continuous around the posterior border of the mylohyoid muscle. Dental infections.

They account for 80% of the cases.

Mixed infections involving both aerobes and anaerobes are common. 

Alpha-haemolytic Streptococci, Staphylococci and Bacteroides groups are common

questions.text: Being normal at birth, a child at 2 years presented with history of intellectual disability and delayed motor development. He subsequently developed gouty arthritis and increased episodes of aggression. He died at the age of 25 from renal failure. Considering the following self-inflicted injuries to his fingers identify the likely enzyme deficiency.
questions.solution:
The clinical features given above are of classic for Lesch-Nyhan disease (LND) which results from the deficiency of hypoxanthine-guanine phophoribosyl transferase (HPRT) enzyme.

LND is a rare X-linked disorder in purine salvage that is due to deficiency of HPRT.

Salient features of LND can be remembered by the mnemonic LESCH.

  • L – Lips and fingers self-injury
  • E – Excessive uric acid production leading to gout
  • S – Self mutilation and aggression
  • C – Choreoathetosis
  • H – HPRT deficiency

Most children are normal at birth but then begin to exhibit developmental delays, intellectual disability, and other neurologic signs after a few months.

Diagnosis is definitive with HPRT enzyme analysis.

Medical management is aimed at prevention of renal failure and it involves treatment of hyperuricemia with alkalinization and allopurinol.

Other modalities of management are aimed at mood stabilization, reduction of anxiety and self-mutilation.

Option B – Adenosine deaminase (ADA) deficiency causes immune-deficiency and is one of the major causes of severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID).

Option C – Ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency causes increased ammonia concentrations causing ataxia and death. It is one of the most common urea cycle disorders.

Option D – Phosphomannose isomerase deficiency is a disorder of glycosylation and features include failure to thrive, enteropathy and hepatic fibrosis.

questions.solution:
Fidaxomicin is given in a dose of 200mg twice daily orally.

Fidaxomicin:

  • Fidaxomicin is a narrow-spectrum, macrocyclic antibiotic.
  • It is active against gram-positive aerobes and anaerobes but lacks activity against gram-negative bacteria.
  • Fidaxomicin inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the sigma subunit of RNA polymerase.
  • Systemic absorption is less but fecal concentration is high.
  • It is approved for the treatment for C difficile colitis.
  • Dose : 200 mg orally twice daily.

questions.text: Kimmelsteil Wilson lesion is seen in
questions.solution:
Nodular Glomerulosclerosis  also known as intercapillary glomerulosclerosis or Kimmelstiel-Wilson disease showing nodules of pink hyaline material  in regions of glomerular capillary loops in the glomerulus is classically seen in diabetic nephropathy.

  • Approximately 15% to 30% of individuals with long-term diabetes develop nodular glomerulosclerosis.
  • The glomerular lesion -  Ovoid or spherical, often laminated, nodules of matrix situated in the periphery of the glomerulus which are PAS-positive.
  • This is due to a marked increase in mesangial matrix from damage as a result of non-enzymatic glycosylation of proteins.
  • Uninvolved lobules and glomeruli show striking diffuse mesangial sclerosis
  • Prominent accumulations of hyaline material may be seen in capillary loops (“fibrin caps”) or adherent to Bowman capsules (“capsular drops”).
  • As a consequence of the glomerular and arteriolar lesions, the kidney suffers from ischemia, tubular atrophy and interstitial fibrosis, and usually undergoes overall contraction in size.

questions.text: This booklet by the CDC is related to:
questions.solution:
The shown booklet by the CDC is related to emporiatrics.

Emporiatics is a term used to describe the study of the health of travelers. Travelers encounter unique health risks, especially in the era of jet travel. International travelers often experience various stressors that can weaken their immune response, such as overcrowding, lengthy waiting times, disruptions in eating patterns, and changes in climate and time zones. These factors can lead to symptoms like nausea, indigestion, severe fatigue, and insomnia.

Travelers are recommended prophylactics and vaccines when going to areas with specific endemic diseases.

Other options:

Option A: Nosology is defined more specifically as a scientific classification system for diseases or disorders.

Option B: Ergonomics is the study of matching job requirements and environment to the worker to maximize efficiency, quality, and quantity of work while minimizing work-related musculoskeletal disorders, fatigue, and overexertion.

Option D: Epornithic is a term used for epidemic in bird populations.

II. Histiocytes  B. Placenta 
III. Kupffer cells  C. Connective tissue 
IV. Microglia D. Liver

The correct answer is I-B; II-C; III-D; IV-E; V-A.

Cell  Tissue 
I. Hofbauer cells B. Placenta 
II. Histiocytes  C. Connective tissue 
III. Kupffer cells  D. Liver 
IV. Microglia E. Brain
V. Mesangial cells  A. Kidney

Macrophages can be divided into:

1. Blood macrophages (monocytes) are the largest of the myeloid cells found in the peripheral blood. They survive for 3 days. 
2. Tissue macrophages present in different organs. They survive for months. 
The main functions of macrophages are phagocytosis and antigen presentation.

The specialised (tissue-specific) macrophages present in different tissues are listed below: 

  1. Peripheral blood: Monocytes
  2. Placenta: Hofbauer cells
  3. Liver: Kupffer cells
  4. Brain: Microglial cells
  5. Kidney: Mesangial cells
  6. Lungs: Alveolar macrophages
  7. Bone: Osteoclasts
  8. Connective tissue: Histiocytes

questions.text: In which of the following dermatological conditions is the following manifestation the first to appear?
questions.solution:
• The first and most common manifestation of pityriasis rosea is the herald patch, which tends to be larger than the patches that form later and is usually situated in the thigh, trunk, upper arm, or neck regions.
  • It is a sharply defined, erythematous, round or oval plaque and is soon covered by fine scales.
  • This condition is self-limiting and is considered to be viral in origin.
  • It is known to occur commonly in the age groups between 10 to 35 years.
  • In later parts of the disease, a Christmas tree pattern of patches tends to occur over the skin.
  • Drugs like metronidazole, terbinafine, and clonidine are also known to cause pityriasis rosea-like eruptions.

questions.text: A 3-year-old female presents with microcephaly and short stature. Associated hand wringing movements are present and midline stereotypic behaviour. Which of the following genes is associated with the above disease?
questions.solution:
3-year-old child microcephaly and midline stereotypic behaviour should raise suspicion for Rett syndrome. The gene associated with Rett's syndrome is MECP-2 gene.

  • It is a pervasive development disorder.
  • Is an X linked dominant disease.
  • Age of onset – is from 5 months of disease
  • The child initially has normal milestone development until 1 year of age. This is followed by regression of language and motor milestones.
  • The most important feature is the regression of the acquired skills and head growth retardation.
  • They have associated autistic behaviour with microcephaly, breath holding spells.
  • They can also manifest with midline stereotypic behaviour and loss of hand abilities.

Asperger syndrome

  • Is seen in males after 3 years of age.
  • Speech is preserved to some ability and can have normal intelligence
  • They have impairment in social interaction and development
  • They do not manifest with mental retardation.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with abdominal distension and gross hematuria. On examination, a palpable mass in the right flank and moderate hypertension are noted. A provisional diagnosis of Wilm's tumor is made. All the given features correspond to the respective syndromes involving Wilm's tumor except:
questions.solution:
In Wilm's tumor, the given finding of gonadal dysgenesis is associated with Denys-Drash syndrome and not with Beckwith-Weidemann syndrome. 

Wilms tumour, also known as nephroblastoma, is the most common primary malignant renal tumor of childhood. It is the 2nd most common malignant abdominal tumor in childhood after neuroblastoma. Loss of function mutation of the WT1 gene on chromosome 11p13 is commonly seen in Wilms tumours.

The clinical presentation of Wilms tumor are:

  • Incidental discovery of asymptomatic abdominal mass
  • Hypertension
  • Abdominal pain 
  • Gross painless hematuria. 

The syndromes associated with Wilms tumor are: 

  • WAGR syndrome - aniridia, genitourinary abnormalities, mental retardation
  • Denys-Drash syndrome - early-onset renal failure, gonadal dysgenesis (male pseudohermaphroditism)
  • Beckwith-Weidemann syndrome - hemihypertrophy, organomegaly, macroglossia
  • Fraiser syndrome
  • Fanconi anaemia
  • Trisomy 18
  • Perlman syndrome

The diagnosis can be confirmed by radiological investigations like CT, abdominal ultrasound, and biopsy. Histologically, Wilm's tumour is made of blastemal, stromal, and epithelial cells.

Treatment depends on the stage of the disease and includes: Surgery, and chemotherapy, with or without radiotherapy.

Related Pearl: Syndromic Associations of Wilms Tumor

Syndrome Mutation Features
WAGR Syndrome
  • WT1 and PAX6 deletion on Chr11p
  • Genetic basis- two-hit hypothesis
  • Wilms tumor
  • Aniridia
  • Genital anomalies
  • Mental retardation
Denys–Drash Syndrome
  • Dominant-negative missense mutation of WT1 protein
  • Genetic basis- two-hit hypothesis
  • Gonadal dysgenesis (male pseudo hermaphroditism)
  • Early-onset nephropathy
  • Gonadoblastoma
Beckwith– Wiedemann Syndrome
  • IGF-2 overexpression onWT2 region
  • Genetic basis- genomic imprinting
  • Organomegaly
  • Macroglossia
  • Hemihypertrophy
  • Omphalocele
  • Adrenal cytomegaly
  • Hepatoblastoma
  • Pancreato-blastoma
  • Adrenocortical tumors
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma

Note: Wilms tumor 1 (WT1) protein is a transcriptional activator of genes involved in normal renal and gonadal development. Therefore, genitourinary abnormalities are commonly associated with WT1 gene mutations.

questions.text: A patient aged 63 years, is diagnosed to have severe aplastic anemia. HLA compatible sibling is available. The best option of treatment is:

choices.text: A conventional bone marrow transplantation from the HLA identical sibling
A non- myelo ablative bone marrow transplantation from the HLA identical sibling

questions.solution:
Treatment for elderly patients with severe aplastic anemia is immunosuppression with anti-thymocyte globulin plus cyclosporine.

Treatment of severe aplastic anemia:

Young adults (<40 years) who have HLA matched siblings- Allogenic Bone marrow Transplantation; Adults (>40 years) / without HLA matched sibling -  Anti thymocyte globulin plus cyclosporine

questions.solution:

questions.text: Identify the type of twin pregnancy as seen in the USG
questions.solution:
In the above USG, on looking carefully, we can see the placental tissue in between the 2 sacs, indicating the twin-peak sign is positive.

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins there is a thick septum between the two gestational sacs. It is best identified at the base of the membrane, where a triangular projection is seen. This is known as lambda or twin peak sign. Presence of lambda or twin peak sign indicates dichorionic placenta

questions.text: Perjury is punishable by law according to:
questions.solution:
• Section 191 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) defines perjury which is giving false witness or lying under oath.
  • Section 193 IPC describes the punishment for perjury which is imprisonment upto seven years. 
  • Section 228 IPC describes the offence of intentional insult or interruption to a public servant sitting in a judicial proceeding.
  • Section 299 IPC describes culpable homicide amounting to murder.
  • Section 379 IPC describes the punishment for theft.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of precurrent disinfection?

choices.text: Disinfection of linen after death of patient

questions.solution:
• Precurrent or prophylactic disinfection are done as a prophylactic measure like pasteurization of milk, chlorination of water and hand washing.
  • Concurrent disinfection is application of disinfection methods after discharge of infectious material from the body of an infected person or soiling.
  • Terminal disinfection is done after death of a patient or transfer or after cessation of isolation.

questions.text: Neurapraxia is defined as:

choices.text: The disruption of axons and myelin
The disruption of axons and endoneurial tubes
The temporary failure of nerve function without physical axon disruption
The temporary failure of nerve function with physical axon disruption

questions.solution:
• Neurapraxia is the temporary failure of nerve function without physical axonal disruption.
  • Seddon classification of peripheral nerve injury:
  • Neurapraxia - Axon degeneration does not occur and there is return of normal axonal function occurs over hours to months, often in the 2-4 week range.
  • Axonotmesis: It is the disruption of axons and myelin with intact surrounding connective tissue. Axons degenerate proximally and distally from the area of injury. Distal degeneration is called Wallerian degeneration. Recovery may occur after 18 months.
  • Neurotmesis: It is the disruption of axons and endoneurial tubes and degeneration of proximal and distal axons occurs.

questions.text: The plasma concentration attained by a drug after administering an initial dose of 1000mg in the body is 50mg/L. The half-life of the said drug is about 2 hours. Estimate the rate of elimination of the drug?
questions.solution:
Plasma concentration of the drug = 50mg/L

Initial concentration of drug administered = 1000mg

Half life of the drug = 2 hours

To find: Rate of elimination of drug

Formula:

Apparent volume of distribution = Initial concentration of drug administered / Plasma concentration of drug

V  = 1000 / 50

So apparent volume of distribution = 20 L

Clearance = 0.693× Apparent volume of distribution/ Half life

               = 0.693 ⨯ (20/2)

Clearance  = 6.93 L/hr

Rate of  drug elimination = Plasma concentration ⨯ Clearance

                                    = 50 ⨯ 6.93

                                    = 346.5 mg/hr

So,  Rate of drug elimination= 346.5 mg/hr

questions.text: Thoracic duct does not drain:
questions.solution:
Right upper quadrant of the body drains the lymphatics into the right lymphatic trunk and rest of the body drains into the thoracic duct.

Thoracic duct begins in the abdomen at T-12 vertebral level as the continuation of cisterna chyli.

  • It is usually beaded due to its numerous valves.
  • It drains the body below the diaphragm (lower limbs, pelvis, abdomen) and left half of the body above the diaphragm (thorax, upper limb, head and neck).
  • Thoracic duct passes through the aortic hiatus in the diaphragm and ascends through the posterior mediastinum between the aorta and the azygous vein.
  • At T-5 level, it deviates to the left side and ascends to pass the thoracic inlet.

Tributaries of the thoracic duct:

  • Bilateral (right and left) descending thoracic lymph trunks which convey lymph from lower intercostal spaces (6 – 11).
  • Left upper intercostal lymph trunks, which convey lymph from the upper intercostal spaces (1-5).
  • Mediastinal lymph trunks
  • Left subclavian lymph trunk
  • Left jugular lymph trunk
  • Left bronchomediastinal lymph trunk

Splanchnic nerves pass through the right and left crus of the diaphragm.

The azygous vein may sometimes pass through the right crus of the diaphragm.

The hemizygous vein may sometimes pass through the left crus of the diaphragm.

questions.text: The following is the image of a type of bullet before and after use. Identify it.
questions.solution:
• Dumdum bullets are also called expanding bullets. The tips of these bullets are designed to burst or expand into fragments on impact causing damage over a larger area.
  • Frangible bullets are those which are designed to disintegrate into tiny fragments upon target impact.
  • Tandem bullet is a phenomenon seen when two bullets are fired in one shot with one lying right behind the other. It occurs in old, dirty or country firearms. Sometimes an ejected bullet may get lodged in the barrel and comes out when the next shot is fired – in tandem with that bullet.
  • Incendiary bullets are those filled with a compound that burns or catches fire rapidly.

questions.text: Katayama syndrome involves which parasite(s)?
questions.solution:
• Katayama syndrome is an early clinical manifestation of schistosomiasis caused by schistosomes or blood flukes, especially when Schistosoma japonicum is involved.
  • It is also called acute schistosomiasis and its manifestations include fever, generalized lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly.
  • Praziquantel is the drug of choice for schistosomiasis.

questions.text: Of the following, the most common cause of acute mediastinitis is:
questions.solution:
• Most common cause of acute mediastinitis is either esophageal perforation or post-median sternotomy for cardiac surgery.

questions.text: Epithelium of vagina is derived from
questions.solution: The epithelium of the vagina and the portio vaginalis of the cervix, since it is stratified, are derived from an upgrowth of the epithelium of the urogenital sinus.

questions.text: The complications associated with extubation are all except:

choices.text: Increased blood pressure and heart rate

questions.solution:
The complication associated with extubation is negative pressure pulmonary edema which is a dangerous and potentially fatal condition.

Complications associated with extubation:

  • Laryngospasm and bronchospasm
  • Negative pressure pulmonary edema
  • Upper airway obstruction
  • Hypoventilation
  • Hemodynamic changes (hypertension, tachycardia)
  • Coughing and straining leading to surgical wound dehiscence
  • Laryngeal or airway edema
  • Paradoxical vocal cord motion
  • Arytenoid dislocation
  • Aspiration

Factors associated with increased extubation risk:

  • Airway risk factors
    • known difficult airway
    • airway deterioration (bleeding, edema, trauma)
    • restricted airway access
    • obesity and obstructive sleep apnea
    • aspiration risk
  • General risk factors
    • cardiovascular disease
    • respiratory disease
    • neuromuscular disease
    • metabolic derangements
    • special surgical requirements

questions.text: Ventilation perfusion ratio is maximum at:
questions.solution:
Ventilation-perfusion ration or V/Q ratio is maximum at the apex of the lung.

Ventilation-perfusion ratio (V/Q) is defined as the ratio of lung ventilation to the blood flow or the pulmonary perfusion at rest. 

The normal V/Q ratio at rest for the whole lung is 0.8. At different parts of the lungs, there may be marked differences in the V/Q due to the effect of gravity. In an upright position, there is a linear decrease in both ventilation and perfusion from base to apex. Therefore, the V/Q is maximum in the upper portions of the lungs. 

The below table shows the ventilation, perfusion and V/Q ratio at the apex and base of the lungs. 

  Apex   Base  
Ventilation Minimum Maximum
Perfusion Minimum Maximum
V/Q ratio Maximum Minimum

questions.text: All are favorable prognostic markers in neuroblastoma except
questions.solution:
MYCN amplification correlates with a worse prognosis.

  • Amplification of the MYCN oncogene in neuroblastomas is a molecular event that has possibly the most profound impact on prognosis, particularly when it occurs in tumors that would otherwise portend a good outcome.
  • The presence of MYCN amplification puts the tumor into a “high”-risk category, irrespective of age, stage, or histology.
  • MYCN amplification is present in about 20% to 30% of primary tumors, most presenting as advanced-stage disease, and the degree of amplification correlates with a worse prognosis.
  • MYCN amplification is currently the most important genetic abnormality used in risk stratification of neuroblastic tumors.

questions.text: False statement about Lineweaver burk plot?

choices.text: Also called as double reciprocal plot
X intercept is  inverse of slope
Y intercept is reciprocal of Vmax

questions.solution:
X intercept is -1/Km and is not the inverse of slope.

Lineweaver-Burk plot :

A plot of 1/V as y as a function of 1/[S] as x therefore gives a straight line whose y intercept is 1/Vmax and whose slope is Km/Vmax.

Such a plot is called a double reciprocal or Lineweaver-Burk plot.

So in this plot:

  • X intercept is -1/ Km.
  • Y intercept is 1/Vmax.
  • Slope is Km/Vmax.

Km can be calculated from the slope and y intercept, but is perhaps most readily calculated from the negative x intercept.

questions.text: You are demonstrating findings in a pediatric OSCE examination on a 4-day old neonate. On turning the baby's head to the left, you obtain the finding as shown below. At what age does this reflex normally disappear?
questions.solution:
Asymmetric tonic neck reflex (ATNR) disappears by 6 months postnatally.

The tonic neck reflex is produced by manually rotating the infant’s head to 1 side and observing for the characteristic fencing posture (extension of the arm on the side to which the face is rotated and flexion of the contralateral arm).

An obligatory tonic neck response, in which the infant becomes “stuck” in the fencing posture, is always abnormal and implies a CNS disorder.

Note: According to Ghai Essential Paediatrics, 9th edition, tonic neck reflex disappears by 4 months of age. According to Nelson Paediatrics, 21st edition, tonic neck reflex disappears by 6 months of age. Hence, the answer depends on the reference chosen by the examiner.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with dyspnea and cough. Chest X-ray revealed irregular linear densities, particularly in both lower lobes. Histopathological examination of lung biopsy is shown below. This patient has a higher risk of developing:
questions.solution:
The image shows golden-brown, beaded rods with a translucent center called asbestos bodies which are seen in asbestosis. These patients are at risk of developing both lung carcinoma and mesothelioma.

Asbestosis is marked by diffuse pulmonary interstitial fibrosis and the presence of multiple asbestos bodies.

Option A: Centrilobular emphysema may develop in simple coal workers' pneumoconiosis. 

Option B: Increased susceptibility to tuberculosis is seen in silicosis. 

Option C: Occupational asthma may be triggered by fumes (epoxy resins, plastics), organic and chemical dust (wood, cotton, platinum), gases (toluene), or other chemicals (formaldehyde, penicillin products).

questions.text: A patient presented with the following finding after accidentally spilling hydrofluoric acid over his hand. What is the preferred initial treatment for his condition?
questions.solution:
The initial treatment of hydrofluoric acid skin burns is with the application of calcium carbonate gel.

Immediate first aid to help prevent severe injuries from a chemical burn include:

  • Carefully remove the chemical and any contaminated clothing
    • Remove the chemical and contaminated clothing from contact with the skin and eyes
    • Do not wipe the skin as this may spread contamination
    • If the chemical is dry, brush it off the skin
    • Use gloves or other protective materials to cover hands and, if possible, carefully cut away clothing such as T-shirts, rather than pulling them off over the head
  • Rinse the affected area using as much clean water as possible
    • Rinse the affected area continuously with clean water as soon as possible
    • Try to make sure the water can run off the affected area without pooling on the skin
    • Only use water– do not rub or wipe the area

In very few cases initial management by lavage with water is not useful. Ex: Phosphorous used in some military devices and elemental sodium seen in laboratory explosions.

In hydrofluoric acid burns, initially, calcium gluconate gel is applied topically. Severe burns or burns to large areas of the hand can be subsequently treated with Bier’s blocks containing calcium gluconate 10 % gel. If the burn is with a concentration of greater than 50 %, then acute early excision is indicated due to the chance of hypocalcemia and arrhythmias. Split skin graft application to a hydrofluoric acid wound should be delayed and must not be done initially. 

Note - Although topical calcium gluconate is usually preferred, topical calcium carbonate gels may also be used for treating burns as they are also effective in providing calcium ions to complex the  free fluoride ions to prevent further toxicity.

questions.text: Sjögren's syndrome increases the risk of developing:
questions.solution:
Sjögren's syndrome increases the risk of developing marginal zone B-cell lymphoma (MALToma).

Sjögren's syndrome is characterized by chronic and persistent inflammation of the salivary glands. Initially, there is a polyclonal immune reaction, but additional mutations acquired over time may lead to the development of B-cells which can multiply even in the absence of growth signals. This is the point at which marginal zone lymphoma develops. Recent studies have shown that patients with Sjögren's syndrome are also at an increased risk for multiple myeloma.

Sjögren's syndrome is a chronic disease wherein exocrine glands such as lacrimal and salivary glands undergo immunologically-mediated destruction. This leads to the characteristic features of dry eyes (keratoconjunctivitis sicca) and dry mouth (xerostomia). It can occur in isolation or secondary to other systemic diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis, limited systemic sclerosis, and SLE. 

The patients usually present with drying of the mouth, difficulty in swallowing, and parotid gland enlargement. Ocular involvement may present as a gritty feeling beneath the eyelids. The workup includes the Schirmer test to determine the extent of tear production in the eyes, salivary flow tests, and serum investigations to detect specific antibodies, like anti-Ro and anti-La.  The presence of CD4+ cells on the labial biopsy confirms Sjögren's syndrome.

Related Pearl: Extraglandular manifestations of Sjögren’s syndrome

The extraglandular manifestations of Sjögren’s syndrome are as follows:

  • Non-specific
    • Arthralgia or arthritis - It is the most common extraglandular manifestation. It is usually non-erosive and leads to Jacoud’s arthropathy
    • Raynaud’s phenomenon
  • Accumulation of peri-epithelial lymphocytes
    • Interstitial lung disease - Most common type is non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP)
    • Renal tubular acidosis - Distal (type 1) RTA
    • Primary biliary cirrhosis
  • Immune complex-mediated
    • Small vessel vasculitis - Presents as cutaneous palpable purpura
    • Glomerulonephritis with cryoglobulinemia
    • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Lymphoma
    • Extranodal marginal zone B cell lymphoma of mucosal-associated lymphoid tissue (MALToma).

questions.text: A patient presents with a loss of sensation over the marked area. Which nerve may be damaged?
questions.solution:
The skin over the angle of the mandible is innervated by the great auricular nerve.

Most of the skin covering the face is innervated solely by branches of the trigeminal nerve except the skin over the angle of the mandible which is supplied by the great auricular nerve from the C2 cervical plexus and the ear supplied by the vagus nerve, the facial nerve, and the cervical plexus.

questions.text: Chemical name of Sanger’s reagent is?
questions.solution:
Sanger’s reagent is 1- Flouro 2,4 Dinitro benzene

Sanger’s technique:

  • This was the first technique to determine the sequence of protein.
  • Sanger’s reagent is 1- Flouro 2,4 Dinitro benzene

questions.text: Bioavailability of Ramelteon is?
questions.solution:
Since Ramelteon undergoes extensive first pass metabolism its bioavailability is less than 2%.

Ramelteon:

  • Ramelteon is a synthetic tricyclic analog of melatonin.
  • It is approved for the treatment of insomnia, specifically sleep onset difficulties.
  • Ramelteon binds to the MT1 and MT2 receptors.
  • It is rapidly absorbed from the GIT.
  • But it has a high first pass metabolism, so the bioavailability is nearly  less than  2%.
  • Administered in a dose of  8 mg ½ hour before going to bed, it is shown to hasten sleep onset as well as increase sleep duration, without causing next morning sedation or impairment.
  • Its elimination t½ is 1–3 hours.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presented with intense itching in the ear, pain, and watery discharge with a musty odor. On examination, black-headed filamentous growth was seen resembling wet blotting paper. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis based on the clinical scenario is otomycosis. 

Otomycosis is a fungal infection of the external ear caused commonly by Aspergillus niger, A.fumigatus, or Candida albicans. It is frequently seen in tropical areas and in individuals who use antibiotic drops to treat otitis media/ otitis externa.

Patients present with intense pruritus, discomfort, pain, blocked sensation in the ear, and foul-smelling watery discharge. Otoscopy will show a fungal mass whose appearance depends on the causative organism.

  • Aspergillus niger can be seen as a black-headed, filamentous growth.
  • Aspergillus fumigatus presents as a pale blue or green mass.
  • Candida appears as a white, creamy mass in the ear.

Aural toileting and topical antifungal agents are the primary treatment. Nystatin, clotrimazole, and povidone-iodine are the commonly used antifungals. 2% salicylic acid in alcohol works as a keratolytic to remove the superficial layers of the epidermis along with the fungal mycelia.

Other options:

Option B: Diffuse otitis externa occurs due to bacterial infection of the external ear. It presents as severe pain worsening with jaw movement, discharge of purulent material, and conductive hearing loss. In the chronic phase, meatal skin can undergo scaling and fissuring. 

Option C: Otitis externa hemorrhagica is probably viral in origin. It presents with severe pain and blood-stained discharge due to the rupture of hemorrhagic bullae on the tympanic membrane and meatus.

Option D: Malignant otitis externa occurs due to infection by pseudomonas commonly in diabetics and patients with immunosuppression. Symptoms are similar to otitis externa but examination will reveal granulations in the external auditory canal. It can cause facial nerve paralysis and has a high tendency to spread.

questions.text: A new method of measuring hemoglobin is developed. 9.4, 10.4, 9.6, 9.1, 10.8, 12.1, 10.1, 9.8, 9.2 and 9.5 are the values in ten successive readings. A standard test previously revealed the hemoglobin as 10.2. What is true regarding the given method?
questions.solution:
• This test has high validity and low reliability.
  • The new test doesn’t give the same values on repeat testing, thus it has low reliability.
  • The mean value of all the readings is 10. This predictive accuracy is close to the value of 10.2 from the standard test, making the validity high.

questions.text: While examining the skeletal remains from a bomb blast, a forensic expert decides to use the Gustafson's method for identification of the ages of people killed. Which of the following would you  not assess in this method?
questions.solution:
Tooth length is not assessed in Gustafson’s method.

Gustafson's method of estimation of age of an individual is based on physiological changes in teeth. It is mainly useful in adults over 25 years of age.

Gustafson’s criteria includes:

  • Attrition -  wear and tear changes of occlusal surface
  • Periodontosis -  regression of gums surrounding the tooth resulting in loosening of the tooth and falling
  • Secondary dentin - deposition of dentin in pulp cavity
  • Cementum apposition - deposition of cementum in the root forming incremental lines
  • Root resorption -  involves both cementum and dentin
  • Transparency of the root - This is the most reliable criteria. Canals in dentin get filled with mineral and they become less transparent.

Gustafson's method has now been largely replaced by Lamendin's method.

Other methods of age determination based on teeth:

  • Lamendin's method - It evaluates root dentine translucency, periodontopathy, and tooth length
  • Miles' method - Uses transparency of the root as a single criterion
  • Boyd's method - Determination of age of an infant by counting incremental lines on enamel
  • Stack's method - Determination of age by measuring dimensions of teeth
  • Variation in racemization of amino acids (especially aspartic acid) in dental pulp with age
  • Evaluating the reduction of the pulp chamber through X-rays

questions.text: A young man presents to the OPD with complaints of high-grade fever, and sore throat for the past 3 days. On examination, the submandibular group of lymph nodes were firm and enlarged. What is the level of this lymph node?
questions.solution:
The level of the submandibular group of lymph nodes in the neck is level 1b. 

Other options: 

Option A: Level 1a are submental group of lymph nodes. 

Option C: Level 2 are upper juglar group of lymphnodes. 

Option D: Level 3 are middle juglar group of lymphnodes.

questions.text: Erythema multiforme occurs at:
questions.solution:
• Erythema multiforme (EM) can occur at any age group including neonates and young children.
  • It occurs more frequently when associated with herpes simplex.
  • Drugs like tetracyclines, barbiturates, nevirapine, allopurinol, etc. have been reported to cause EM.
  • EM is a self limiting cytotoxic dermatitis due to hypersensitivity resulting from infection or drugs.

questions.text: What is the cause of Calabar swellings?
questions.solution:
• Loa loa is a filarial nematode that causes loiasis
  • One of the main clinical features of this condition is the presence of Calabar swellings which are localized areas of angioedema and erythema which occur usually at the extremities.
  • It is thought to occur due to hypersensitivity to the worm antigen.
  • Definitive diagnosis of loiasis is done either by detection of microfilaria in peripheral blood or by isolation of adult worm in the eye.
  • Diethylcarbamazine is used for treatment of loiasis.

questions.text: In which of the following the conduction velocity is least?
questions.solution:
The conduction velocity is least in AV node.

The slow conduction in the AV node is caused mainly by diminished numbers of gap junctions between successive cells in the conducting pathways.

questions.text: Deficiency of which of the following complement components causes hereditary angioneurotic edema?
questions.solution:
C1 esterase inhibitor (C1 INH) blocks the activation of C1, the first protein of the classical complement pathway, and inherited deficiency of this inhibitor is the cause of hereditary angioedema.

The targets of C1 inhibitor are proteases, specifically C1r and C1s of the complement cascade, factor XII of the coagulation pathway, and the kallikrein system. Hereditary angioneurotic edema is an autosomal dominant disorder where the deficiency of C1 INH leads to unregulated activation of kallikrein and increased production of vasoactive peptides such as bradykinin. Bradykinin is an inflammatory mediator that caused neutrophil chemotaxis, capillary dilatation with plasma leakage, and smooth muscle relaxation.

Episodes of edema affecting the skin and mucosal surfaces such as the larynx and the gastrointestinal tract, which may result in life-threatening asphyxia or nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea after minor trauma or emotional stress.

Clinical syndromes associated with genetic deficiencies of complement components are as follows:

Deficiency Syndrome
C1 esterase inhibitor Hereditary angioneurotic edema
C1, C2, C4 SLE and other collagen vascular diseases

C3 and its regulatory protein

C3b inactivator

 Severe recurrent pyogenic infections
C5 to C8 Bacteremia, mainly with gram-negative diplococci, toxoplasmosis
C9 No particular disease

questions.text: Intracameral voriconazole is given in:
questions.solution:
• Intracameral voriconazole is given in corneal ulcer.
  • Intracameral administration is localized drug delivery into the chambers of the eye, i.e., anterior or posterior.
  • Fungal corneal ulcer or mycotic keratitis is usually caused by Aspergillus.
  • It is a dry looking ulcer with feathery borders with satellite lesions usually seen.
  • Immune ring of Wesseley is also commonly seen.
  • Natamycin is another drug used in fungal corneal ulcers as a topical drug.
  • Drug widely used in fungal endophthalmitis is amphotericin B.

questions.text: Using a graphic plan of all events and activities to be completed in order to reach an end objective is part of:
questions.solution:
Network analysis involves using a graphic plan or network of all events and activities to be completed.

Related Pearl: Network Analysis in Health Management

A network is a graphic plan of all events and activities to be completed in order to reach an end objective.

Two types of network analysis: PERT and CPM

1. Programme Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT)

  • An arrow diagram of all events in logical sequence is drawn.
  • Time to finish each activity can be calculated and critical activities can be identified.
  • It aids in planning, scheduling and monitoring of the project.

2. Critical Path Method (CPM)

  • The longest path of the network is called the critical path.
  • A delay in the critical path will cause a delay in the entire project.

questions.text: Identify the anomaly
questions.solution:
The given picture is of craniorachischisis which is the most severe form of dysraphism. It occurs due to total failure of neural tube closure.

Cranio indicates cranium, rachi indicates spine, schisis indicates split. The brain and spinal chord are exposed to the surrounding amniotic fluid, resulting in necrosis, degeneration or angioma-like formations.

Alpha fetoprotein (AFP) is found in amniotic fluid and maternal serum, and is an indicator of neural tube defects.

Neural tube defect prophylaxis byFolic Acid: 400 mcg (WHO) and 500 mcg (MoHFW- India).

Spina bifida is a developmental anomaly characterized by defective closure of vertebral arch associated with maternal folic acid deficiency and is classified into various types.

Several forms is Spina bifida occulta.

- Failure of vertebrae to close around spinal cord (tufts of hair often evident),

- No increase in AFP

  • Spinal meningocele (spina bifida cystica)

- Meninges extend out of defective spinal canal

- raised AFP

  • Meningomyelocele

- Meninges and spinal cord extend out of spinal canal

- Raised AFP

  • Myeloschisis (most severe form)

- Neural tissue is visible externally

- Raised AFP

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presented with complaints of burning sensations of the palms and soles. History revealed a predominantly vegetarian diet and workup showed low levels of serum B12. Treatment for this patient must not be administered through which of the following routes?
questions.solution:
Cyanocobalamin (Vitamin B12) should never be administered through the intravenous route. This is because IV administration will result in almost all of the vitamin being lost in the urine.

Cyanocobalamin is usually administered by the intramuscular or deep subcutaneous route. In patients with a previous history of sensitivity to vitamin B12 injections, an intradermal skin test of cyanocobalamine should be done.

questions.text: Which of the following attains adult size before birth?
questions.solution:
Ear ossicles attain adult size before birth. 

The development of the middle ear:

  • The ossicles are full-sized cartilage models by 15 weeks of gestation.
  • Endochondral ossification is complete by 25 weeks.
  • The middle ear is adult-sized at birth.

questions.text: What surgery is being done?
questions.solution:
• The images above show twisted bowel and the Ladd procedure is the operation of choice of rotational anomalies of the intestine.
  • In this surgery, the bowel is de-rotated in a counter-clockwise fashion.
  • The peritoneal attachment between the caecum and retro-peritoneum (Ladd band) is divided.
  • The base of the mesentery is widened, and an appendectomy is performed.
  • Option B - Bianchi surgery: It is an intestinal lengthening procedure used in short bowel syndrome.
  • Option C – Duhamel procedure: It is used in Hirschsprung disease where aganglionic rectal stump is left in place and the ganglionated normal colon is pulled posterior.
  • Option D – Swenson’s procedure: It is is used in Hirschsprung disease where aganglionic bowel is removed and a coloanal anastomosis is performed.

questions.text: Cobblestone feel of uterosacral ligament is seen in
questions.solution: If the uterosacral ligaments and the pouch of Douglas feel thickened and shotty with multiple small nodules palpable through the posterior fornix, the diagnosis of endometriosis becomes reasonably certain. These are described as cobblestone feel of uterosacral ligaments.

questions.text: A 5 year old child is scheduled for strabismus correction. Induction of anesthesia is uneventful. After conjunctival incision as the surgeon grasps the medial rectus the anesthetist looks at the cardiac monitor. Why do you think he did that?

choices.text: He wanted to check the depth of anesthesia
He wanted to be sure that BP did not fall
He wanted to see is there was an oculocardiac reflex
He wanted to make sure there were no ventricular dysrhythmias which normally accompany incision

questions.solution:
The Oculocardiac reflex is a trigemino-vagal-reflex (afferent through trigeminal nerve, efferent through vagus nerve)

It is most common in pediatrics undergoing strabismus surgery.

Caused by traction on extraocular muscles or pressure on eyeball

  • Strabismus surgery
  • Cataract surgery
  • Enucleation
  • Retinal detachment surgery
  • Orbital hematoma
  • Ocular trauma

The manifestation can range from bradycardia (most common) to sinus arrest and ventricular ectopic to ventricular fibrillation.

Treatment:

  • Temporary cessation of surgery until heart rate increases
  • Adequate ventilation and dept of anesthesia

IV atropine 10mg/kg

questions.text: You discover that there is evidence of cardiac malformation in a fetus during a routine USG scan at 16 weeks. What is the minimum level of fasting blood sugar at which you can suspect overt diabetes?
questions.solution:
Overt diabetes is when fasting blood sugar is ≥ 126 mg/dl. Overt diabetics are women who are known to have diabetes before pregnancy. 

A patient is said to have overt diabetes if:

  • Fasting blood sugar ≥ 126 mg/dL
  • A random blood sugar of ≥ 200 mg/dL
  • HbA1c of ≥ 6.5%

The maternal complication of diabetes:

  • increased Miscarriage and preterm labor.
  • increased incidence of preeclampsia
  • polyhydramnios
  • prolongation of labor due to shoulder dystocia, operative interference, and cephalo-pelvic disproportion.

Fetal and Neonatal complications of diabetes:

  • fetal macrosomia (birth weight > 4kg)
  • congenital malformations - Musculoskeletal, urogenital, and CNS anomalies.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient presents with bilateral conductive deafness, bloody nasal discharge, and hemoptysis. Chest radiography shows multiple and bilateral cavities. Serum creatinine is 3 mg/dL. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical findings point to a diagnosis of granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's granulomatosis).

Wegener's granulomatosis is characterized by necrotizing vasculitis of small vessels with the formation of granulomas at multiple sites. The classic feature of this disease is the involvement of the triad of upper and lower respiratory tracts, and the kidneys.

Patients present with paranasal sinus pain and discharge (purulent or bloody) and may end up developing nasal septal perforation and saddle nose deformity. Eustachian tube block can lead to otitis media with effusion and conductive hearing loss. Lower respiratory tract involvement presents as cough and hemoptysis due to multiple, bilateral cavitary infiltrates in the lungs. Renal pathology typically evolves quickly into rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. It is important to note that there is no granuloma formation in the kidney and there is no immune complex deposition either.

Laboratory findings show elevated levels of c-ANCA (antiproteinase-3 ANCA), ESR, CRP, and RA factor. The diagnosis can be established by demonstration of necrotizing granulomatous inflammation on tissue biopsy in a suspected patient. The presence of ANCA antibodies is adjunct as they may be absent in some patients.

Related Pearl: Churg Strauss

  • Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Churg Strauss Syndrome) is a necrotising granulomatous vasculitis. It involves small and medium-sized muscular arteries, capillaries, veins, and venules.
  • It presents as a combination of asthma, peripheral and tissue eosinophilia, extravascular granulomas, vasculitis of multiple organ systems.
  • The characteristic histopathological shows granulomatous reaction that can be present in the tissue or even within the walls of the vessels.
  •  Common organs affected in this condition are:
    • Lung- presents with severe asthmatic attacks and pulmonary infiltrates
    • Mononueritis multiplex
    • Skin lesions- presents as purpura and subcutaneous nodules
    • Renal involvement
  • Important laboratory findings seen are:
    • Eosinophilia with levels of > 1000 cells/µL
    • Presence of pANCA antibodies
  • Treatment- Glucocorticoids and mepolizumab (anti-IL-5 antibody) have been found to effective.

questions.text: A 4-year-old male child presents with fever and fatigue of 2 months duration. On examination, he has generalized lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, hepatomegaly, and testicular enlargement. Lab investigations show LDH- 644mg/dl, TLC - 41900/mm3, Hb -9.7g/dl and Plt- 104000/uL. Marrow is hypercellular and aspirate is as shown below. The cells are myeloperoxidase negative and often contain periodic acid-Schiff–positive cytoplasmic material. All the following are favourable prognostic markers for the condition except:
questions.solution:
Age younger than 2 years in ALL is associated with worse prognosis largely because of the strong association of infantile ALL with translocations involving the MLL gene.

Factors associated with a worse prognosis:

  1. Age younger than 2 years
  2. Presentation in adolescence or adulthood
  3. Peripheral blood blast counts greater than 100,000, which probably reflects a high tumor burden

Favorable prognostic markers include

  1. Age between 2 and 10 years
  2. A low white cell count
  3. Hyperdiploidy
  4. Trisomy of chromosomes 4, 7, and 10
  5. The presence of a t(12;21)

questions.text: Calcification of adrenal gland is a feature of which of the following disease?
questions.solution:
Wolman disease is characterized by Calcification of Adrenal gland.

Wolman Disease:

  • It is cholesterol ester storage disease.
  • Autosomal recessive inheritance
  • Enzyme deficiency- Acid lysosomal lipase
  • Cholesterol esters and triglycerides accumulate
  • Onset -  Infantile period
  • Features:
    • Hepatomegaly
    • Adrenal calcification
    • Mild mental retardation
  • Death occurs before 1 year of age

questions.text: Arden index is related to:
questions.solution:
Arden index is related to electro-oculography (EOG).

Arden index is the ratio of the light peak over the dark trough. A value above 185 is normal and below 150 is abnormal.

In electrooculography, electrodes are used to pick up changes in the resting ocular potential when the eyes are moved. These changes are recorded in accordance with changes in illumination. It indicates the activity of the pigmentary epithelium and the outer segments of visual receptors.

Other options:

Option A: Electroretinography measures changes in the resting potential of the eye, induced by stimulating the eye with light.

Option C: Specific alterations in an electroencephalogram (EEG) caused by visual stimuli are called as visual evoked responses (VER).

Option D: Perimetry is the measurement of a person’s field of vision.

choices.text: It has more than 20 deliveries per month
It has less than 20 deliveries per month

questions.solution:

  • Type B PHC with 20 or more deliveries per month.

questions.text: CA 125 is elevated in
questions.solution:
• CA-125, glycoprotein and cell surface antigen, is raised to more than 35 U/mL in 80% cases of endometriosis and the level is directly proportional to the extent of the disease.
  • It is also raised in abdominal tuberculosis, PID, malignant epithelial ovarian tumour, chronic liver disease and in 2% normal women, especially during menstruation.
  • It may not be helpful in the initial diagnosis, once the diagnosis is established, raised level of CA-125 indicates either persistence or recurrence of the disease in the follow-up.

questions.text: Hanging cast is used in
questions.solution:
Hanging cast is used in some cases of lower-third fractures of the humerus.

Conservative methods used in most cases fracture shaft of Humerus:

  • U-slab

U-slab is supported with a triangular sling. Once the fracture unites, the slab is removed (approximately 6-8 weeks) and shoulder exercises started

  • Hanging cast

The weight of the limb and the cast is supposed to provide necessary traction to keep the fracture aligned.

  • Chest-arm bandage

This much immobilisation is sufficient for fracture of the humerus in children less than five years of age

questions.solution:
The given reports show an elevated anion gap of 27 [Na - (Cl + HCO3) = 140 - (18+95)]. Elevated anion gap metabolic acidosis is seen in all of the above conditions, except renal tubular acidosis.

Renal tubular acidosis (RTA) is associated with loss of alkali in urine. Reciprocal changes in the levels of Cl and HCO3 result in a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis.

From the data given in the question:

  • Cervical dilatation is 1 cm, hence score = 1.
  • Effacement is 30%, hence score = 0
  • Station of the head is –1, hence score = 2
  • Consistency of cervix is soft, hence score = 2
  • Position of the cervix is posterior, hence score = 0

Hence, Bishop's score is 1+0+2+2+0 = 5.

Related Pearl: Bishop’s Score (Modified)

Head-Station -3 -2 -1, 0 +1, +2

Total score = 13

Favourable= 6-13

Unfavourable= 0-5

Note: 

  • According to NICE guidelines, a score of 6-13 is favorable for induction of labour.
  • According to Williams Obstetrics (26th edition), a score of 9 or more indicates a high likelihood of successful induction.

questions.text: In 1884, a paper on the local anaesthetic action of cocaine in ophthalmic surgery was published and was lauded by ophthalmologists all over the world. Who proposed it?
questions.solution:
Cocaine was the first topical anaesthetic and was discovered by Carl Koller in 1884.

He first introduced cocaine as a topical anaesthetic for ophthalmologic surgery of the cornea. Thereafter, cocaine was used for intradermal infiltration and nerve blocks by William Halsted.

Joseph Priestley: First synthesized nitrous oxide.

Humphrey Davy: Experimented with nitrous oxide and named it laughing gas.

William Morton: Introduced ether anaesthesia.

Dr Carl Koller (1857-1944) was a medical student in Vienna when he befriended a young Sigmund Freud (1856-1939). Experimenting on themselves, they studied a new wonder drug named cocaine. Dr Koller was nicknamed "Coca Koller" by Freud, as discovered in one of the many letters they shared.

questions.text: All are anti-apoptotic factors except
questions.solution:
BAX is a pro-apoptotic factor

  • Intrinsic or mitochondrial pathway of apoptosis results from increased permeability of the mitochondrial outer membrane with consequent release of death-inducing (pro-apoptotic) factors.
  • BCL2 family of proteins-can be divided into three groups based on their pro-apoptotic or antiapoptotic function.
  • Anti-apoptotic -  BCL2, BCL-XL, and MCL1.  Reside in outer mitochondrial membranes as well as the cytosol and ER membranes. By keeping the mitochondrial outer membrane impermeable they prevent leakage of cytochrome c and other death-inducing proteins into the cytosol.
  • Pro-apoptotic. BAX and BAK are the two prototypic members of this group.
  • Upon activation, BAX and BAK oligomerize within the outer mitochondrial protein and promote mitochondrial outer membrane permeability which leads to leakage of death-inducing proteins into the cytosol.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman was brought to the emergency room after she lost consciousness briefly during a speech. An ECG was taken immediately. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows a constant PR interval in each successive cycle followed by a dropped QRS (P wave fails to produce a QRS complex). This pattern is suggestive of Mobitz type II block.

Mobitz type II block is characterized by an intermittent failure of conduction of the p wave without any change in the preceding impulses.  

The dropped QRS is marked in the image below:

Note: Bradyarrhythmias that cause syncope include those due to severe sinus node dysfunction and AV block( Mobitz type II block, complete AV block). Syncope due to bradycardia or asystole is referred to as Stokes-Adams attack.

questions.text: A 50-year-old post-renal transplant patient on cyclosporine presented with the following lesion. You suspect it to be a cancerous growth. Which of the following statements regarding this condition is false?

choices.text: It has a high grade malignant potential
The most common site is extremities

questions.solution:
The above image showing purple-colored plaques on the ala and tip of the nose in an immunocompromised patient is suggestive of Kaposi sarcoma. It is mostly seen in extremities, commonly on feet and occasionally on hands, ears, and nose, and has a low-grade malignant potential.

Skin lesions are usually purple and multifocal which eventually evolve into plaques and tumors. Lymph nodes, mucosae, and viscera may be involved as the disease progresses, although this can occur without skin involvement.

questions.text: Mechanism of action of Riociguat is?
questions.solution:
Riociguat is an allosteric activator of soluble guanylyl cyclase.

questions.text: White infarcts are seen in all the following organs except:
questions.solution:
White infarcts occur with arterial occlusions in solid organs with end-arterial circulation like heart, spleen, and kidney, and where tissue density limits the seepage of blood from adjoining capillary beds into the necrotic area.

Red infarcts occur:

  1. with venous occlusions (e.g., testicular torsion)
  2. in loose, spongy tissues (e.g., lung) where blood can collect in the infracted zone
  3. in tissues with dual circulations (e.g., lung and small intestine) that allow blood to flow from an unobstructed parallel supply into a necrotic zone.
  4. in tissues previously congested by sluggish venous outflow
  5. when flow  is reestablished to a site of previous arterial occlusion and necrosis (e.g., following angioplasty of an arterial obstruction).
  • Infarcts are areas of ischemic necrosis most commonly caused by arterial occlusion (typically due to thrombosis or embolization); venous outflow obstruction is a less frequent cause.
  • Infarcts caused by venous occlusion or occurring in spongy tissues with dual blood supply and where blood can collect typically are hemorrhagic (red); those caused by arterial occlusion in compact tissues typically are pale (white).
  • Whether or not vascular occlusion causes tissue infarction is influenced by collateral blood supplies, the rate at which an obstruction develops, intrinsic tissue susceptibility to ischemic injury, and blood oxygenation.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male patient presented with hematuria, pedal edema, and hypertension. He also gives a history of episodes of hemoptysis in the past. His renal biopsy showed crescent formation and a linear pattern of staining on immunofluorescence. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and the renal biopsy findings are suggestive of Goodpasture syndrome also known as anti-glomerular basement membrane (GBM) disease. It is a type II hypersensitivity reaction.

In Goodpasture syndrome, antibodies that are directed against the GBM also cross-react with the basement membrane of the alveoli of the lung. This causes the characteristic clinical picture of pulmonary hemorrhage associated with renal failure. The antibodies are targetted against a peptide in the non-collagenous portion of the α3 chain of collagen type IV. In the kidney, anti-GBM antibodies lead to rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis, which is characterized by the formation of crescents. On immunofluorescence, deposition of IgG and C3 is seen in a linear pattern along the GBM.

Other options:

Option A: Mutation of type IV (α5 chain) collagen is responsible for Alport syndrome, which presents with haematuria, ophthalmologic conditions (such as anterior lenticonus), and sensorineural hearing loss. This condition most commonly occurs as an X-linked dominant condition, and males express the full syndrome. Female heterozygotes typically present with just hematuria. Electron microscopy findings include a glomerular basement membrane with alternating portions of thickening and thinning associated with splitting the of lamina densa, known as a basket-weave appearance.

Option C: The typical sign of IgA nephropathy is episodic hematuria linked to the deposition of IgA in the mesangium. Recurrent episodes of macroscopic hematuria during or right after an upper respiratory infection, frequently accompanied by proteinuria, and persistent asymptomatic microscopic hematuria is the two most typical manifestations of IgA nephropathy. Mesangial and paramesangial dense deposits are seen on electron microscopy.

Option D: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener granulomatosis) involves the upper and lower respiratory tracts and kidneys. A c-ANCA pattern with positive anti-PR3 antibodies is seen. A lung biopsy will show evidence of vasculitis and necrotizing granuloma formation, which is characteristic of this disease. Renal abnormalities vary from mild instances characterized by focal glomerular necrosis and isolated thrombosis of the capillary loops (known as focal and segmental necrotizing glomerulonephritis), to more severe glomerular lesions featuring widespread necrosis accompanied by the proliferation of parietal cells, leading to the formation of crescents (referred to as crescentic glomerulonephritis).

questions.text: A mother observed deterioration in her young child's academic performance and loss of interest in everyday activities for the last few weeks. The presence of reduced ceruloplasmin levels, motor incoordination, and hepatomegaly suggest the patient is suffering from Wilson’s disease. Sparse depigmented hair is not a feature of Wilson's disease. It is a feature of Menke's disease.

Wilson's disease is caused due to a mutation in the ATP7B gene that leads to excess deposition of free copper within tissues.

questions.text: Thymic hypoplasia with diminished T cell immunity is seen in
questions.solution:
Patients with DiGeorge syndrome have thymic hypoplasia, with resultant T-cell immunodeficiency, parathyroid hypoplasia giving rise to hypocalcemia, cardiac malformations and mild facial anomalies.

Deletion of genes at chromosomal locus 22q11.2 gives rise to malformations affecting the face, heart, thymus, and parathyroids. The resulting disorders are recognized as:

  •  DiGeorge syndrome (thymic hypoplasia with diminished T-cell immunity and parathyroid hypoplasia with hypocalcemia) and
  •  Velocardiofacial syndrome (congenital heart disease involving outflow tracts, facial dysmorphism, and developmental delay)
  • Fragile X syndrome results from loss of FMR1 gene function and is characterized by mental retardation, macroorchidism,abnormal facial features, hyperextensible joints, a high arched palate, and mitral valve prolapsed
  • Prader- Willi syndrome, -  mental retardation, short stature, hypotonia, hyperphagia, small
  • hands and feet, and hypogonadism.
  • Angelman syndrome - mental retardation, ataxia, seizures, and inappropriate laughter.

questions.text: Leukemia is an occupational hazard most commonly related to which of the following?
questions.solution:

  • Skin cancer is an occupational hazard related to coke oven workers.
  • Sugarcane dust or bagasse inhalation leads can lead to bagassosis.
  • Chrysolite is a type of asbestos. Although it less harmful, generally exposure to asbestos leads to asbestosis.

                                = 40.625%

So Transferrin saturation = 40.6%

questions.text: Which of the following presents with pseudobubo?

questions.text: A young patient was posted for liver transplantation surgery. He was given cisatracurium for neuromuscular blockade. Which of the following is not true regarding the class to which the drug belongs?

choices.text: Their action is potentiated by Mg2+ and antagonized by Ca2+
Characteristic train of 4 and tetanic fade present

questions.solution:
Cistacurium is metabolised by Hoffman's degradation. Mivacurium is metabolised by pseudocholinesterase.

Cisatracurium belongs to the class of non-depolarizing muscle relaxants (NDMR). Cisatracurium is preferred in patients undergoing liver transplantation because of its organ-independent elimination and reduced histamine release. It is a competitive inhibitor at acetylcholine receptors.

Neuromuscular blockade can be done by depolarising or non-depolarizing agents.

Other options:

The illustration shown below shows variations of a train of fade patterns by various muscle relaxants.
