questions.text: All of the following statements about Hurthle cell carcinoma of thyroid are true, except?

choices.text: They are a variant of follicular carcinoma

questions.solution:
• Hurthle cell carcinoma has a poor prognosis.

Hurthle cell carcinoma is a variant of follicular neoplasm in which oxyphil cells predominate histologically.

questions.text: Given below is the X-ray of a patient with chronic renal failure. The cause for the deformity is
questions.solution:
The above X-ray shows alternating bands of sclerosis and lucency throught, resembling a rugger jersey and is hence called a rugger jersey spine.

Rugger jersey spine is seen in renal osteodystrophy and is due to hyperparathyroidism.

In response to increased bone resorption due to excess parathyroid hormone (PTH) secretion and subsequent loss of bone mass, osteoblasts form an increased amount of osteoid that does not contain hydroxyapatite but does appear opaque on radiographs.

The sclerotic bands represent accumulations of excess osteoid and appear opaque because of their increased volume when compared to normal bone.

questions.text: Which of the following does not  grow in artificial media?
questions.solution:
• Rhinosporidium seeberi which causes the chronic granulomatous disease, rhinosporidiosis has not been cultured in artificial media.
  • Thus its diagnosis is based on clinical features and histological examination with special stains(gomori methanamine stain, PAS)

Recent taxonomy suggests Rhinosporidium seeberi is in a new eukaryotic group of protists known as Mesomycetozoa.

questions.text: The laser procedure that is most commonly used for treating iris neovascularization is:
questions.solution:
• Panretinal photocoagulation (PRP) is the most common laser procedure in treating iris neovascularization (rubeosis iridis) which results in neovascular glaucoma due to formation of zip-like adhesions of iris to cornea at the angle.
  • This pathology usually follows extensive retinal ischemia as seen in association with CRVO and proliferative DR.
  • Anti-VEGF agents and cryotherapy are also used in treatment of neovascular glaucoma.
  • Trabeculectomy with anti-fibroblastic agents or an anterior chamber drainage implant are used to relieve the raised intraocular pressure.

questions.text: True about ranula are all except

choices.text: Bluish, translucent, cystic swelling in the floor of mouth
Marsupialisation or excision is the treatment

questions.solution:
Ranula is a mucous extravasation cyst originating from the sublingual gland in the floor of mouth due to obstruction of its duct.

Features :

  • Translucent, bluish, soft, cystic fluctuant swelling present below the tongue pushing it upwards and medially thus interfering with speech, mastication, respiration, and swallowing.
  • Plunging ranula presents as asymptomatic, enlarging neck mass.

Management:

  • Marsupialisation – unroofing the cyst and tacking the edges of the cyst to adjacent tissues.
  • Sclerosing agents like bleomycin.
  • Sublingual gland excision – recurrence rate is very low.

questions.text: A post-disaster process in which the less injured are given higher priority is called:
questions.solution:
• Reverse triage is a situation where the less injured are treated earlier than the ones that are injured more.
  • This is used in wars and military settings where soldiers may need to return to the field of battle soon after treatment.
  • It is also done when there is scarcity of medical resources after a disaster.

questions.text: Components of the District Mental Health Programme does not include:
questions.solution:
• Components of the District Mental Health Programme are:
    • Training of all mental health workers at the nodal institute in state
    • Increasing public awareness by education to reduce stigma
    • Early detection and treatment
    • Providing data for future planning, improvement in service and research
  • Activities by the DMHP for positive mental health: school mental health services, college counseling services, work place stress management and suicide prevention services.

questions.text: Following IVP imaging is diagnostic of
questions.solution:
Intravenous pyelogram showed ectatic distal collecting ducts contain the microcalcification which is called bouquet of flowers appearance.

There is also dilated contrast filled tubules within the renal medulla that is known as paintbrush appearance. These findings are characteristic for medullary sponge kidney (MSK) on intravenous pyelogram.

Medullary sponge kidney represents a developmental defect affecting the formation of collecting tubules and results in cystic dilatation of medullary and papillary portions of collecting ducts.

questions.text: Folie a duex is a type of:
questions.solution:
Folie a deux is an induced delusional disorder, is also known as shared psychotic disorder / symbiotic psychosis.

Here there is sharing of delusions between 2 persons.

There is a dominant person who induces the delusion in another dependant person. This dependant person accepts the delusion from the dominant person. If the dominant person is removed (seperated from the dependent person) then the delusion in the non-dominant person disappears.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a history of recurrent late-trimester abortions is in preterm labor, presumed to be due to chorioamnionitis. She has received one dose of betamethasone injection. This is a precious pregnancy and the relatives are concerned about prematurity-related complications in the baby. Which of the following is useful for assessing lung maturity in this fetus?
questions.solution:
The lecithin–sphingomyelin ratio (L/S ratio) is an amniotic fluid test used to assess fetal lung maturity. L/S ratio of < 2 in amniotic fluid indicates lung immaturity. 

Surfactant starts appearing in the fetal lung by 20 weeks of gestation. Levels indicating lung maturity are detected after 35 weeks.

Surfactant is a complex mixture of lipids, proteins, and carbohydrates produced by type II pneumocytes in the lung epithelium. The absence of surfactant in the liquid film lining the alveoli causes an increase in surface tension and alveolar collapse. If not treated, such atelectasis leads to increased work of breathing, intrapulmonary shunting, ventilation-perfusion mismatch, hypoxia, and eventually respiratory failure. 

The relative concentration of the phospholipids lecithin (L) and sphingomyelin (S) is an indicator of lung maturity. The outward flow of pulmonary secretions from the fetal lungs into the amniotic fluid maintains the level of lecithin and sphingomyelin equally until 32–33 weeks gestation when the lecithin concentration begins to increase significantly while sphingomyelin remains nearly the same. An L–S ratio of 2.5 or more indicates fetal lung maturity while an L/S ratio of less than 1.5 is associated with a high risk of infant respiratory distress syndrome.

Other tests done to assess fetal lung maturity are:

  • Shake test/bubble test
  • Phosphatidyl glycerol measurement
  • Surfactant:albumin ratio
  • Lamellar body counts

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about hepatorenal syndrome (HRS)?

choices.text: There is always involvement of renal pathology
Treatment includes midodrine, octreotide and intravenous albumin
Type 2 HRS has better outcome than Type 1 HRS
Renal vasoconstriction and refractory ascites is associated with HRS

questions.solution:
• Hepatorenal syndrome usually occurs with no involvement of renal pathology and is seen associated with advanced cirrhosis or acute liver failure.
  • Increased renal vascular resistance is seen in HRS and it usually associated with refractory ascites.
  • Type 2 HRS shows reduction in GFR with elevation in serum creatinine levels and has better outcome than Type 1 HRS.
  • Current treatment includes midodrine, octreotide and intravenous albumin.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with GERD has no improvement after long-term medical therapy. He underwent surgical treatment for GERD. Identify the procedure.
questions.solution:
The procedure in the given image shows a 360-degree wrap, which is known as Nissen's fundoplication; this procedure is done for GERD. Nissen's fundoplication is a complete fundoplication procedure.

Fundoplication is the procedure in which the fundus of the stomach is wrapped around the lower end of the esophagus. In the Nissen's fundoplication procedure, the fundus is wrapped the entire 360 degrees around the esophagus. 

The most common complication of Nissen’s fundoplication is the gas-bloat syndrome. In this condition, patients are unable to belch gas from the stomach into the oesophagus. This causes increased gas in the stomach, resulting in a bloating sensation, abdominal discomfort, and flatulence.

Other options:

Option A: The toupet procedure is the re-creation of a sphincter around the EGJ done by wrapping the fundus around the oesophagus. A posterior 180-270-degree wrap is used.

Option B: The Dor procedure is fundoplication, most commonly used in the setting of the esophagal myotomy. It consists of an anterior 180-degree wrap.

Option C: Watson's fundoplication is a 90-degree anterior fundoplication. It is reported to achieve good reflux control while permitting burping and active vomiting and reducing gas bloat.

questions.text: Paltauf’s spots are seen in:
questions.solution:
Paltauf’s spots or hemorrhages are lung findings seen in cases of drowning.

They are usually subpleural and appear as pale red to brownish spots, some as large as a fingernail. They are caused by the tearing of the capillary walls caused by massive over-distension of the lung tissue.

Other findings in drowning include cutis anserina, which refers to the appearance of goosebumps, and edema aquosum, characterized by waterlogged tissues. Emphysema aquosum occurs when the lungs are distended with fluid, giving them a spongy texture. Frothing and Cadaveric spasms may also be seen.

Diatom detection can be used to confirm drowning. This involves identifying diatoms (microscopic algae) in the bone marrow or other organs, which can indicate that water was inhaled before death.

questions.text: Which of the following nuclei do not belong to the general visceral efferent column?
questions.solution:
Nucleus ambiguus does not belong to the general visceral efferent (GVE) column.

The general visceral efferent columns contain nuclei of parasympathetic cranial nerves:

  • III - Edinger-Westphal nucleus
  • VII - Superior salivatory nucleus
  • IX - Inferior salivatory nucleus
  • X - Dorsal motor nucleus of vagus.

Nucleus ambiguus belongs to the special visceral efferent (SVE) column.

The special visceral efferent column contains neurons innervating muscles developed from the pharyngeal arches:

  • Motor nucleus of V nerve- muscles of mastication
  • Motor nucleus of VII nerve- muscles of facial expression
  • Nucleus ambiguus (IX, X, XI)- stylopharyngeus, pharyngeal, external laryngeal, oesophageal striated muscles, muscles of the soft palate, sternocleidomastoid, and trapezius.

questions.text: A 50-year-old HIV-positive male presents with raised violaceous plaques. Microscopy shows a lesion in the dermis lined encompassing small vessels and slitlike spaces containing red cells with marked hemorrhage, hemosiderin pigment, and mononuclear inflammation. Mitotic figures are also seen. Which organism is associated with this tumor?
questions.solution:
Kaposi sarcoma (KS) is a vascular neoplasm caused by human herpesvirus 8 (HHV8) a γ-herpesvirus that is highly associated with acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS).

Four forms of KS based on population demographics and risks:

  • Classic KS - Older men of Mediterranean, Middle Eastern, or Eastern European descent. It can be associated with malignancy or altered immunity but is not associated with HIV infection.
  • Endemic African KS -  Typically occurs in HIV-seronegative individuals younger than age 40 and can follow an indolent or aggressive course, with prominent lymph node and visceral involvement, occurs in prepubertal children; the prognosis is poor, with an almost 100% mortality within 3 years.
  • Transplant-associated KS occurs in solid organ transplant recipients in the setting of T-cell immunosuppression. Characteristically involves lymph nodes, mucosa, and viscera; cutaneous lesions may be absent.
  • AIDS-associated (epidemic) KS is an AIDS-defining illness - it represents the most common HIV-related malignancy. AIDS-associated KS often involves lymph nodes and disseminates widely to viscera early in its course.

The given images show coalescent red-purple macules and plaques of the skin and the histologic appearance of Kaposi sarcoma, demonstrating sheets of proliferating spindle cells.

Other options-

Option B: Epstein Barr virus causes Burkitt’s lymphoma, Hodgkin’s lymphoma, Post-transplant lymphoproliferative disease, and Nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

Option C: Bartonella henselae causes bacillary angiomatosis especially in immunocompromised patients and is characterised by proliferating cystic blood filled spaces surrounded by a fibromyxoid matrix containing the bacteria. Circumscribed lesions with lobular capillary proliferation and round, open vessels with cuboidal endothelial cells protruding into the vascular lumen are also seen. Mitotic figures are not seen.

Option D: Human papillomavirus type 16 and 18 causes cervical cancer due to mutation in RAS gene.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is effective in the delayed phase of post-chemotherapy nausea and vomiting?
questions.solution:
Aprepitant is the drug preferred for delayed onset vomiting after cancer chemotherapy.

Nausea and vomiting associated with chemotherapy occur in two phases:

  • The acute phase is seen within 24 hours and occurs in almost all patients receiving chemotherapy. In response to chemotherapeutic agents, the enterochromaffin cells in the small intestine secrete serotonin, which acts on the 5HT3 receptors and causes vomiting. This phase is treated by 5HT3 antagonists such as ondansetron, granisetron, and palanosetron.
     
  • The delayed phase is seen on days 2-5 and occurs only in some patients. It occurs in response to stimulation of NK-1 receptors by substance P. 5HT3 antagonists are not effective against the delayed phase, and NK-1 receptor antagonists are used in these patients. 

NK-1 receptor antagonists include aprepitant and its parenteral formulation, fosaprepitant, rolapitant, and netupitant. These drugs are usually administered in combination with 5HT3 antagonists and dexamethasone for highly emetogenic chemotherapy. A fixed-dose combination of netupitant and palanosetron has been approved to cover both the acute and delayed phase of post-chemotherapy nausea and vomiting.

questions.text: The following fundus picture shows an enlarged optic disc within an area of chorioretinal pigmentary changes incorporated in a funnel shaped excavation. What is the name of this anomaly?
questions.solution:
• The image is of the morning glory disc anomaly which is a rare congenital anomaly of the optic disc.
  • It is called so as it resembles a morning glory flower.
  • In this anomaly, a funnel shaped excavation incorporates the optic disc.
  • The disc itself is enlarged and is surrounded by an area of peripapillary chorioretinal pigmentary changes.
  • There is a white glial tuft within the center of the disc.
  • Prognosis of vision is poor in the presence of this anomaly and the risk of serous retinal detachment is considerable.
  • Other midline cranial defects are also common with the presence of this anomaly.

questions.text: Which of the following pairs of toxins produced by Staphylococcus aureus are called synergohymenotropic toxins?
questions.solution:
γ-toxin and Panton-Valentine-toxin (leucocidin) of Staphylococcus aureus are called synergohymenotropic toxins.

Synergohymenotropic (synergo - working together, hymenotropic - form pores) toxins are a family of bicomponent toxins that act through the synergistic activity of 2 non-associated secretory proteins - class F and class S proteins. Gamma hemolysin has two components necessary for its hemolytic action. It is encoded by three genes HlgA and HlgC (belonging to class S) and HlgB (belonging to class F), resulting in 2 pairs of class S and F components - HlgA and HlgB, or HlgC and HlgB.

Panton-Valentine Leucocidin is composed of two components- S and F - encoded by two contiguous and cotranscribed genes, lukS-PV and lukF-PV. It is associated with the majority of community-associated methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (CA-MRSA).

questions.text: Endocrine amyloid is associated with all the following tumours except
questions.solution:
• Microscopic deposits of localized amyloid may be found in certain endocrine tumors, such
  • as medullary carcinoma of the thyroid gland, islet tumors of the pancreas, pheochromocytomas, and undifferentiated carcinomas of the stomach, and in the islets of Langerhans in individuals with type 2 diabetes mellitus.
  • In these settings the amyloidogenic proteins seem to be derived either from polypeptide hormones (e.g., medullary carcinoma) or from unique proteins (e.g., islet amyloid polypeptide).
  • In medullary carcinomas of the thyroid, the presence of amyloid is an essential diagnostic feature.

questions.text: All of the following are implicated in risk of development of adenocarcinoma in ulcerative colitis except:
questions.solution:
• Pseudopolyps are not considered a risk factor for carcinoma in ulcerative colitis.
  • Risk factors for colorectal carcinoma as a sequelae of ulcerative colitis:
    • Prolonged duration of disease
    • Pancolonic disease
    • Continuously active disease
    • Severity of inflammation
  • The cumulative risk for cancer increases with the duration of the disease reaching 25% at 25 years, 35% at 30 years, 45% at 35 years and 65% at 40 years.

  • Renal tumors + adrenal tumors
 CDKN1B

questions.text: False about Parinaud’s syndrome is:
questions.solution:
Parinaud syndrome:

  • Also known as dorsal midbrain syndrome.
  • It is s a distinct supranuclear vertical gaze disorder caused by damage to the posterior commissure.
  • It is a classic sign of hydrocephalus from aqueductal stenosis.
  • Features include
    • Loss of upgaze
    • Convergence-retraction nystagmus on attempted upgaze
    • Downward ocular deviation ("setting sun"sign)
    • Lid retraction (Collier's sign)
    • Skew deviation
    • Pseudoabducens palsy
    • Light -near dissociation of the pupils
  • Other causes of parinaud syndrome include
    • Pineal region or midbrain tumors
    • Cysticercosis
    • Stroke

questions.text: Fetal blood loss in abnormal cord insertion is seen in
questions.solution:
Normally the umbilical cord is inserted at the centre of the fetal surface of placenta. In velamentous placenta, the unsupported umbilical vessels lie below the presenting part and run across the cervical os and are called vasa previa. They are torn either spontaneously or during rupture of membranes.

Color-flow Doppler (TVS) is helpful for antenatal diagnosis. Detection of nucleated red blood cells (Singer’s alkali denaturation test) or fetal hemoglobin (Apt test) is diagnostic.

Management depends on fetal gestational age, severity of bleeding, persistence or recurrence of bleeding.

  • Considering the risks of bleeding, patient with confirmed vasa previa, needs antenatal admission at 28–32 weeks of gestation. Expectant management can be done in selected cases for fetal lung maturity similar to placenta previa. Antenatal corticosteroids should be given.
  • Any case with bleeding vasa previa, delivery should be done by category-1 emergency cesarean section. Intrapartum diagnosis of vasa previa, needs expeditious delivery.
  • A case of confirmed vasa previa at term (≥37 weeks) should be delivered by elective cesarean section prior to onset of labor.
  • Neonatal blood transfusion may be needed.

questions.text: Select the false statement regarding frozen shoulder______

choices.text: X-ray of the shoulder is usually normal
Pain in frozen shoulder radiates to the wrist
Movements will never be regained back to normal

questions.solution:
• In frozen shoulder, external rotation is most affected followed by abduction and then forward flexion; internal rotation is the least affected. One important fact to be remembered is that pain in frozen shoulder does not radiate below the elbow. Even if the movements recover, they will never be regained back to normal. X-ray of the shoulder is usually normal; only in some cases sclerosis may be seen on the outer edge of the greater tuberosity.
  • Note: Reeves classified frozen shoulder into three stages. First, comes the stage of pain lasting for 3 to 9 months. Second is the stage of stiffness where pain gradually decreases and this lasts for 4 to 12 months. During the last stage, that is, the stage of recovery, the patient will have no pain and the movements have recovered except that the movements are never regained back to normal.

questions.solution:
Arlt’s line is a conjunctival sign of trachoma.

questions.text: In which of the following cases is glove and stocking hypostasis most likely to be seen?
questions.solution:
Glove and stocking hypostasis indicates postmortem staining of legs, feet, hands, and forearm. This occurs in the vertical suspension of the body as in hanging where these parts form the dependant parts.

Sites of postmortem hypostasis depending on the position of the body:

Position of the body Sites of hypostasis
Supine Back except for shoulder blades, buttocks, and calves (contact pallor)
Vertical as in hanging Legs, feet, forearm, and hands (glove and stock hypostasis)
Drowning Face, the upper part of chest, hands, lower arms
Inverted like in drunken persons Head and neck

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with a worsening headache for 8 months. A left sub frontal mass is resected. Microscopy is as seen below and tumor cells express progesterone receptors.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Microscopy shows a tumor with meningothelial whorls, syncytial cells with indistinct cell membranes and psammoma bodies. Most likely diagnosis is a meningioma.

Meningioma: They are predominantly benign tumors of adults, usually attached to the dura, that arise from the meningothelial cells of the arachnoid.

  • Meningiomas may be found along any of the external surfaces of the brain as well as within the ventricular system, where they arise from the stromal arachnoid cells of the choroid plexus.
  • Prior radiation therapy to the head and neck, typically is a risk factor.
  • The most common cytogenetic abnormality is loss of chromosome 22, especially the long arm (22q).
  • Meningiomas are a common lesion in the setting of NF2 (multiple sites, especially in association with acoustic neuromas or glial tumors.
  • The surface of the mass is usually encapsulated.
  • They may also grow en plaque, in which the tumor spreads in a sheetlike fashion along the surface of the dura. This form is commonly associated with hyperostotic reactive changes in the adjacent bone.
  • The lesions may contain numerous calcified psammoma bodies.

Histological subtypes:

  • WHO Grade I – Menigothelial, fibroblastic, transitional, psammomatous, secretory, microcystic
  • WHO Grade II- Clear cell, chordoid, atypical
  • Grade III – Papillary, rhabdoid, anaplastic
  • Atypical meningiomas (WHO grade II/IV) - a higher rate of recurrence and more aggressive local growth
  • Anaplastic (malignant) meningioma (WHO grade III/IV) - highly aggressive tumor with the appearance of a high-grade sarcoma
  • Immunoreactive for epithelial membrane antigen
  • Keratin is restricted to lesions with the secretory pattern, and these tumors are also positive for carcinoembryonic antigen
  • Moderate (3: 2) female predominance, usually solitary, but when present at multiple sites, the possibility of neurofibromatosis type 2 should be considered.
  • Meningiomas often express progesterone receptors and may grow more rapidly during pregnancy.

questions.text: The following symbol would most likely be plastered on boxes containing which of the following wastes?

choices.text: Soiled clothes of an HCV patient
Metallic body implants from hip replacement

questions.solution:
• The symbol represents cytotoxic wastes and chemotherapeutic drugs come under this category.
  • Cytotoxic wastes are wastes generated from the use of cytotoxic drugs like the drugs themselves, needles and syringes used and gowns or wastes from those undergoing such treatments.
  • Cytotoxic wastes include drugs that are carcinogenic, genotoxic, teratogenic, etc.

questions.text: Children display pseudoparalysis of Parrot in which infectious disease?
questions.solution:
Pseudoparalysis of Parrot is a clinical sign in children with congenital syphilis.

Bone involvement in congenital syphilis leads to pain due to osteochondritis, which results in children refusing to move the affected limb. This is phenomenon is named pseudoparalysis of Parrot. Other features of congenital syphilis include thrombocytopenia, persistent rhinitis, and vasculitis.

Some manifestations of late-stage congenital syphilis are summarized in the table below.

SYMPTOMS/SIGNS DESCRIPTION/COMMENTS
Olympian brow The bony prominence of the forehead caused by persistent or recurrent periostitis
Clavicular or Higoumenakis sign Unilateral or bilateral thickening of the sternoclavicular portion of the clavicle
Saber shins Anterior bowing of the midportion of the tibia
Scaphoid scapula Convexity along the medial border of the scapula
Hutchinson Teeth Peg-shaped notches under central incisors. They erupt during 6th yr of life with abnormal enamel, resulting in a notch along the biting surface
Mulberry molars Abnormal 1st lower (6yr) molars characterized by small biting surface and excessive number of cusps
Saddle nose Depression of the nasal root, a result of syphilitic rhinitis destroying adjacent bone or cartilage
Rhagades Linear scars that extended in a spoke-like pattern from previous mucocutaneous fissures of the mouth, anus, and genitalia
Juvenile paresis Latent meningovascular infection; it is rare and typically occurs during adolescence with behavioral changes, focal seizures, or loss of intellectual function
Juvenile tabes Rare spinal cord involvement and cardiovascular involvement with aortitis
Hutchinson triad Hutchinson teeth, interstitial keratitis, and 8th nerve deafness
Clutton joint Unilateral or bilateral painless joint swelling (usually involving knees) from synovitis with sterile synovial fluid; spontaneous remission usually occurs after several weeks
Interstitial keratitis Manifests with intense photophobia and lacrimation, followed within weeks or months by corneal opacification and complete blindness
8th nerve deafness Maybe unilateral or bilateral. Appears at any age, manifests initially as vertigo and high-tone hearing loss, and progress to permanent deafness
A perforated nasal septum may be an associated abnormality.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presented to the OPD with a fever for the past 5 days. On examination, tender lesions were found on his extremities as marked below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis for this patient is infective endocarditis.

Tender violaceous subcutaneous nodules in the fingers shown in the image are Osler nodes. They usually occur in the pads of fingers and toes but can also occur on the thenar and hypothenar eminences.

Other lesions that are highly suggestive of infective endocarditis include:

  • Roth spots: These are exudative, edematous hemorrhagic lesions of the retina with pale centres.
  • Janeway lesions: They are nontender, slightly raised haemorrhages on the palms and soles. The image is shown below.

questions.text: An unconscious patient of head injury comes in the casualty. On examination there is raised intracranial pressure. Which anesthetic agent is contraindicated?
questions.solution:
Ketamine is contraindicated in raised intracranial pressure.

Ketamine is a direct cardiac-depressant by inhibiting Ca2+ channels, but this is masked by its indirect sympathomimetic action which may cause

Increase in all pressures like ICT, IOP, BP and hence contraindicated in:

  • Raised intracranial pressure/pathology with mass effect/ head injury
  • Hypertension, Ischemic heart disease, arterial aneurysm
  • Open eye injury, glaucoma or vitreoretinal surgery
    • Most potent bronchodilator with intact upper airway reflexes. Hence anaesthesia of choice in asthma (status asthmaticus).
    • Increased BP, CO, HR, cardiac metabolism, oxygen demand
    • Increased cerebral blood flow/ metabolism/ oxygen consumption and seizures.
    • Increases muscle tone and is an arrhythmogenic.
  • Preferred anaesthetic agent in head injury:
    • Thiopentone (Cerebro protective)
    • Propofol
    • Etomidate (protects against circulatory depression)
    • Isoflurane

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented with thunderclap headaches and seizures. There is no history of trauma. Non-contrast CT was done and is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of a thunderclap headache and seizures with the given CT scan showing hyperdense areas corresponding to blood in the subarachnoid basal cisterns suggest a diagnosis of subarachnoid hemorrhage.

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is the bleeding into the subarachnoid space, which is the area between the arachnoid membrane and the pia mater surrounding the brain. It usually occurs due to bleeding from a ruptured aneurysm or arteriovenous malformation. Most of the ruptured aneurysms are located at the circle of Willis.

Patients present with a sudden and severe headache referred to as thunderclap headache, which may be associated with vomiting, decreased consciousness, and seizures. Neck stiffness and photophobia may develop after a few hours.

Non-contrast CT scan is the imaging modality of choice if done within 12 hours. It shows an increased density of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) spaces. A lumbar puncture should be done if there is a strong suspicion of SAH but negative CT findings. It is ideally done 12 hours later. This allows for red blood cell lysis to occur and bilirubin to be detected in the CSF.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: La belle indifference is seen in___________
questions.solution:
La belle indifference is seen in all of the above conditions.

La-belle indifference: It refers to absence of concern towards one’s problem despite having severe disability. Initially La-belle indifference was thought to be characteristic of conversion disorder. However, it is also seen in multiple sclerosis, parietal lobe lesion and dissociative disorder.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man has treatment-resistant gonorrhea. You plan to send a sample of his urethral discharge to the lab for culture and sensitivity testing. What transport media would you use for this purpose?
questions.solution:
Stuart’s medium is the transport media used for Neisseria gonorrheae and Neisseria meningitidis.

Stuart’s medium is a semisolid, non-nutrient medium, which prevents microbial proliferation. It ensures that microorganisms present are able to survive for a sufficiently long period of time.

questions.text: Most popular conduit chosen for bypass is the:
questions.solution:
• The most popular conduit with a high patency rate is the internal thoracic artery (98% to 5 years).
  • The use of both internal thoracic arteries has shown to increase event-free survival in a number of studies.
  • The second most popular conduit is the radial artery which is preferred over the greater saphenous vein which has a 5 year patency of only 5%.
  • Dacron graft is a collagen-impregnated, knitted graft that is used to perform the proximal aortic anastomosis in aortofemoral bypass. It can also be used in aortic valve repair.

questions.text: Alpha 1 antitrypsin (A1A) clearance is measured in the diagnosis of:
questions.solution:
• Alpha 1 antitrypsin (A1A) clearance is measured for the diagnosis of protein-losing enteropathies.

questions.text: All of the following tumor markers are properly matched, except:
questions.solution:
Among the following, option C is not matched properly. AFP or alpha-fetoprotein is raised in non-seminomatous germ cell tumors of the testis. It can also be elevated in liver cell cancers.

AFP is a plasma protein produced by the embryonic yolk sac and the fetal liver. The AFP levels in serum, amniotic fluid, and urine are used to screen for congenital abnormalities and tumors in adults. 

Non-seminomatous germ cell tumors are frequently occurring testicular tumors. They comprise choriocarcinoma, embryonal carcinoma, teratoma, and yolk cell carcinoma. 

Tumour Features Morphology
Embryonal carcinoma Seen in 20-30 years
Aggressive		 The cut surface shows a variegated appearance.
Histologically, the alveolar or tubular patterns of cell growth with papillary folds are seen
Yolk sac tumor Also known as endodermal sinus tumor
Most common in infants and children till 3 years		 Schiller-Duval bodies are characteristic. They appear like glomeruli in the visceral and parietal region with a central core of capillaries. 
Teratoma Second most common tumor in infants Comprises neural tissues, muscle bundles, cartilage, epithelium embedded in a fibrous or myxoid stroma
Choriocarcinoma Highly malignant type. Serum hCG (Human chorionic gonadotropin) is markedly elevated Made of cytotrophoblasts and syncytiotrophoblasts. Cytotrophoblasts are regular, polygonal cells with distinct borders and a clear cytoplasm while syncytiotrophoblasts are large multinucleated cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm.

Other options:

Option A: CEA or carcinoembryonic antigen is elevated in colon carcinomas, carcinomas of the stomach, lung, and heart.

Option B: CA 15-3 is elevated in breast cancers

Option C: Calcitonin is elevated in medullary carcinoma of the thyroid.

questions.solution: Nitrogen atom in urea are contributed from Ammonium and Aspartate.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with lower abdominal pain, which is worse during menstruation. Laparoscopic examination of the pelvis demonstrates multiple small brown spots on the surface of pelvic structures and extensive fibrous adhesions between tubes, ovaries, and other structures. A biopsy is done and microscopy is as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Microscopy shows glands resembling endometrial glands surrounded by endometrial stroma in the ovary. The most likely diagnosis is endometriosis. 

Endometriosis is defined by the presence of ectopic endometrial tissue at a site outside of the uterus. Includes both endometrial glands and stroma, but may consist only of stroma in some cases. 

It occurs in the following sites, in descending order of frequency

  • Ovaries
  • Uterine ligaments
  • Rectovaginal septum
  • Cul de sac
  • Pelvic peritoneum
  • Large and small bowel and appendix
  • Mucosa of the cervix, vagina, and fallopian tubes
  • Laparotomy scars.

It is principally a disease of women in active reproductive life, most often in the third and fourth decades. It causes infertility, dysmenorrhea (painful menstruation), pelvic pain, and other problems. Endometriotic lesions bleed periodically in response to both extrinsic cyclic (ovarian) and intrinsic hormonal stimulation.

The diagnosis is readily made when both endometrial glands and stroma are present with or without the presence of hemosiderin. In rare cases, only the stroma is identified.

Atypical endometriosis, the likely precursor to endometriosis-related ovarian carcinoma, has two morphologic appearances. One consists of cytologic atypia of the epithelium lining the endometriotic cyst without major architectural changes. The second is marked by glandular crowding due to excessive epithelial proliferation, often associated with cytologic atypia, producing an appearance that resembles complex atypical endometrial hyperplasia.

Other options

Option A- Adenomyosis is characterized by foci of the endometrium deep in the myometrium.

Option B- Chronic endometritis is a chronic inflammation of the endometrium.

Option C- Metastatic endometrial carcinoma would be characterized by abnormal glands and cytologic atypia.

questions.text: What is the zona orbicularis related to?
questions.solution:
Zona orbicularis is related to the neck of femur. They are the circular fibers of the capsule of hip joint.

Capsule of the hip joint is made up of 2 sets of fibers: 

  • Circular fibers or zona orbicularis - They are internal and form a collar around the neck of femur. They are blended with the pubofemoral and ischiofemoral ligaments
  • Longitudinal fibers - They are external. These fibers are numerous in the anterosuperior region and are joined by iliofemoral ligament.

The image given below shows the zona orbicularis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of the condition shown in the following image?
questions.solution:
The above image is of a symblepharon which is not a sequelae of herpetic keratitis.

Symblepharon:

  • It is the adhesion of the lid to the globe of the eye.
  • Adhesion of raw surfaces of parts of the bulbar and palpebral conjunctiva during healing leads to the formation of a symblepharon.

questions.text: Accidental ingestion of the insect shown below is associated with which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
The insect is identified as the Spanish fly. Accidental consumption is associated with priapism.

Spanish fly is a winged insect with a length of 2 cm and a breadth of 0.6 cm with greenish-black color and shiny wings. It contains the toxic active principle cantharidin.

The active principle can be absorbed through the skin and all mucosa. On local application to the skin or mucosa, it is associated with redness of skin, and burning pain followed by vesication of the skin. The sequela of cantharides ingestion involves priapism. Features of this poisoning are severe thirst, dysphagia, priapism, genital pain, tenesmus, and convulsions resulting in coma and death. Abortion can occur if the woman is pregnant.

Treatment is symptomatic and if ingested, stomach wash needs to be done along with the administration of demulcents.

Other Options: 

Option A: Acrodynia is seen in chronic mercury poisoning, in which there is pain and pink discoloration of the hands and feet.

Option C: Raindrop pigmentation is a finely mottled brown change on skin flexures, temples, eyelids, and necks seen in arsenic poisoning.

Option D: Magnan’s sign is seen in cocaine addicts where they experience and interpret paraesthesia as the constant movement of a foreign body or bugs under their skin.

questions.text: A mother brought her 16-year-old boy with a unilateral profuse nosebleed. After successful control of bleeding, a CT scan confirmed the diagnosis of juvenile angiofibroma. What is the reason for it to cause excessive bleeding?
questions.solution:
Angiofibroma is made of vascular and fibrous tissues. Vessels of angiofibroma lack contractile components, they are just endothelium-lined spaces with no elastic or muscle coat. 

This accounts for severe bleeding as the vessels lose the ability to contract. Hence the bleeding cannot be controlled by the application of adrenaline. Therefore, the biopsy is contraindicated.

questions.text: You are treating a college student for acne. While examining him, you observe the following finding. What initial treatment will you recommend for this finding?
questions.solution:
This patient has limited alopecia areata as seen by the well-circumscribed patch of hair loss. Intra-lesional steroids are the first-line treatment.

The following treatment options are used in alopecia areata.

  • First line: Intra-lesional corticosteroids - Depot steroid (hydrocortisone acetate 25 mg/mL or triamcinolone acetonide 5–10 mg/mL)
  • Second line: Oral corticosteroids are used if initial treatment fails.
  • Third line: Contact immunotherapy. It works by inducing mild contact dermatitis on the scalp by applying an allergen.

questions.text: What is the ideal time to stop hormone replacement therapy before surgery?
questions.solution:
Hormone replacement therapy should be stopped six weeks prior to surgery.

Latest guidelines say that aspirin can be continued.

Clopidogrel should be stopped 10 days before surgery.

Anticonvulsants and anti-Parkinson’s drugs can be continued.

Lithium must be stopped 24 hours ahead of surgery.

questions.text: Insulin and glucagon can be identified in fetal pancreas by

choices.text: Insulin at 12 weeks, glucagon at 8 weeks
Insulin at 9-10 weeks, glucagon at 8 weeks
Insulin at 12 weeks, glucagon at 14 weeks

questions.solution:
Insulin containing granules can be identified in fetal pancreas by 9-10 weeks but insulin secretion (identified in fetal plasma) by 12 weeks.

Glucagon can be identified in fetal pancreas by 8 weeks but it is secreted only after birth.

questions.text: Triad of normal pressure hydrocephalus includes all except?
questions.solution:
Motor weakness is not a component of triad of Normal pressure hydrocephalus.

Normal pressure hydrocephalus:

  • It is caused by obstruction to the normal CSF flow in the cerebral convexity and delayed absorption into the venous system.
  • Caused by conditions producing scarring of basilar meninges
  • Communicating hydrocephalus is seen
  • It is a triad of
    • Abnormal gait
    • Dementia
    • Urinay incontinence
  • Papilloedema is not seen
  • Enlarged lateral ventrical with little or no cortical atrophy is the feature
  • Treatment-  Ventriculo peritoneal shunting
  • CSF parameters are normal except for the high range of pressure

questions.text: Ethanol ingestion results in enhanced diuresis. What is the most probable mechanism causing this?

choices.text: Inhibition of ADH action in collecting tubules
Stimulation of ADH action in collecting tubules
Stimulation of ADH release from pituitary gland
Inhibition of ADH release from pituitary gland

questions.solution:
Ethanol inhibits the release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH)/ vasopressin from the posterior pituitary gland. This results in enhanced diuresis observed with ethanol ingestion.

Inhibition of ADH action in collecting tubules is not the mechanism by which alcohol induces diuresis. Stimulation of ADH release or action will have an antidiuretic action.

questions.text: All the following arachadonic acid metabolites cause vasodilatation except
questions.solution:
Thromboxane A2 causes vasoconstriction.

  • Prostaglandins are produced from arachidonic acid
  • The most prostaglandins  in inflammation are PGE2, PGD2, PGF2a, PGI2 (prostacyclin), and TxA2 (thromboxane A2)
  • Platelets contain the enzyme thromboxane synthase and is a  potent platelet-aggregating agent and vasoconstrictor.
  • Vascular endothelium lacks thromboxane synthase but possesses prostacyclin synthase, which is responsible for the formation of prostacyclin (PGI2) and its stable end product PGF1a.
  • Prostacyclin is a vasodilator and a potent inhibitor of platelet aggregation
  • A thromboxane-prostacyclin imbalance has been implicated as an early event in thrombus formation in coronary and cerebral blood vessels. 
  • PGD2 and PGE2 cause vasodilation and increases the permeability of postcapillary venules, thus potentiating edema formation.

Arachadonic acid metabolites in inflammation

Action Eicosanoid
Vasodilation Prostaglandins PGI2, PGE1, PGE2, PGD
Vasoconstriction Thromboxane A2, Leukotrienes C4, D4, E4
Increased vascular permeability Leukotrienes C4, D4, E4
Chemotaxis,Leukocyte adhesions Leukotrienes  B4, HETE
HETE, hydroxyeicosatetraenoic acid

questions.text: The windkessel effect is seen in___.
questions.solution:
The windkessel effect is seen in large elastic vessels.

The aorta, the pulmonary artery, and their major branches have a large amount of elastin in their walls. Hence, they have a high elastic recoil effect. This property of elastic recoil is called windkessel effect (windkessel is a German word for the elastic reservoir).

This recoil of the vessels that have been stretched during systole helps to propel the blood forward during diastole thus maintaining a continuous flow throughout the cardiac cycle.

Related Pearl: Types of Blood Vessels

Types of Blood Vessels

TYPES

FEATURES

Windkessel vessels

Aorta and large arteries.

Abundant elastic tissues in the inner and external elastic lamina

Shows elastic recoil (windkessel effect) when stretched

Resistance vessels

Arterioles

Have less elastic tissue and lot of smooth muscle (maximum wall thickness to lumen ratio)

Major site of resistance to blood flow

Exchange vessels

Capillaries

Do not have smooth muscles, consist of single layer of endothelial cells surrounded by a basement membrane

Site of exchange of nutrients, water and gases

Types

  • Continuous- brain, retina (have tight junctions)
  • Fenestrated- glomeruli, choroid plexus
  • Sinusoidal- liver, spleen

Blood flow regulation is by contraction and relaxation of the arterioles and precapillary sphincter

Capacitance vessels

Venules & veins

Thin-walled, easily distensible (maximum percentage of blood volume)

Shunt vessels

AV anastomoses

Have thick muscular walls with rich innervation

Found in – finger tips, ear lobes

questions.text: A 50-year-old man was brought with forgetfulness, behavioral changes, and visual hallucinations for the past 4 months. He is not able to button his shirt and tie his shoelaces for the last 1 month. Diagnosis of a subacute spongiform encephalopathy is made. This is caused by:
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of memory loss with incoordination is suggestive of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD), a type of subacute spongiform encephalopathy, which is caused by prions.

Prions are proteinaceous infective particles that are transmissible. They are virus-like agents devoid of nucleic acid. They are small particles, resistant to heat, UV rays, and nucleases, and sensitive to proteases.

The pathogenic mechanism is the proliferation of an abnormal prion protein (PrPsc) which is derived from the normal cellular prion protein (PrPc). The accumulation of PrPsc in the CNS as diffuse deposits and in the form of plaques disrupts the architecture and function of the brain.

They are slow viral diseases that produce chronic progressive degenerative diseases of the CNS. They are collectively called subacute spongiform encephalopathies and includes Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, kuru and Gerstmann-Sträussler syndrome. Most of these diseases are rapidly progressive and even fatal.

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) is a human prion disease. It is subacute, presenile encephalopathy, with progressive incoordination and dementia, ending fatally in about a year. Both sporadic and inherited forms of the disease have been seen. Iatrogenic CJD has occurred after corneal transplantation and injection of the pituitary growth hormone, presumably from donors who had the infection.

Other options:

Option A: Lentivirus belongs to a group A slow viruses. It causes a slowly progressive infection in sheep. 

Option B: Cryptosporidium parvum causes chronic profuse diarrhea in immunocompromised patients, which can lead to water and electrolyte depletion and weight loss.

Option D: Burkholderia cepacia usually causes fatal necrotizing pneumonia in cystic fibrosis patients.

Related Pearl: Slow Virus Diseases

Slow virus diseases are characterized by a long asymptomatic period, often months or years in duration, between the introduction of the infectious agent and the appearance of clinical illness.

It can be classified into 3 groups:

Group A: Slowly progressive infections of sheep

  • Visna
  • Medi

Group B: Prion diseases

Prion Diseases of Animals

  • Scrapie
  • MINK encephalopathy
  • Bovine spongiform encephalopathy

Prion Diseases of Humans

  • CJD
  • Kuru
  • Gerstmann-Straussler-Scheinkersyndrome
  • Fatal familial insomnia

Group C

  • SSPE
  • PML

Related Pearl: Differential diagnosis of dementia

  • Frontotemporal atrophy on neuroimaging
Dementia with Lewy bodies
  • Visual Hallucination
  • Spontaneous parkinsonism
  • Fluctuating cognition
Normal-pressure hydrocephalus
  • Gait abnormalities 
  • Urinary Incontinence
  • Dementia
  • Dilated ventricles on neuroimaging
Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease
(Prion disease)

  • Rapidly progressive

questions.text: Which of the following sites is the most common location for incomplete canalization causing congenital dacryocystitis?
questions.solution:
• In the image, A is the horizontal canaliculus, B is the common canaliculus and C is the valve of Hasner.
  • The valve of Hasner is the most common site of incomplete canalization leading to congenital dacryocystitis.
  • Infection is common in these cases and aggressive therapy is required if it occurs, especially in infants and children.

questions.text: Improvement in nasal patency on drawing the cheeks laterally is done in which of the following
questions.solution:
• Cottle test - It is used in nasal obstruction due to abnormality of the nasal valve. In this test, cheek is drawn laterally while the patient breathes quietly. If the nasal airway improves on the test side, the test is positive and indicates abnormality of the vestibular component of nasal valve.
  • Epley’s manoeuvre is used in treatment of BPPV.
  • Trotter’s method is used in treatment of epistaxis. In Trotter’s method patient is made to sit, leaning a little forward over a basin to spit any blood and breathe quietly from the mouth.
  • Heimlich manoeuvre is followed in accidental inhalation of foreign body. Procedure: Stand behind the person and place your arms around his lower chest and give four abdominal thrusts. The residual air in the lungs may dislodge the foreign body providing some airway.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with swelling and pain for 6 months over the upper tibia. His radiographic image is shown below. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child with prolonged swelling and pain over the upper tibia, along with a radiograph showing a lytic lesion with a dense sclerotic rim and minimal periosteal reaction, suggests the diagnosis of Brodie's abscess.

Brodie's abscess is a localized form of subacute osteomyelitis that occurs when organisms of low virulence infect an immunocompetent host. The abscess is walled off by the thickening of the surrounding bone trabeculae. It most commonly involves the metaphysis of the proximal tibia and distal femur.

The patient is typically a child or adolescent experiencing prolonged pain near a large joint for several weeks or months. Symptoms may include a limp, slight swelling, muscle wasting, and localized tenderness.

The typical radiographic finding is a circumscribed, round or oval radiolucent cavity measuring 1-2 cm in diameter, surrounded by a halo of sclerosis, with minimal or no periosteal reaction. The radioisotope scan shows markedly increased activity. MRI may be helpful in diagnosis. Open biopsy with curettage is indicated if there is any doubt in the diagnosis.

Differential diagnoses include:

  • Cystic tuberculosis
  • Eosinophilic granuloma
  • Osteoid osteoma
  • Ewing's sarcoma

Treatment:

  • Immobilization and antibiotics (flucloxacillin and fusidic acid) intravenous for 4-5 days, followed by oral administration for another 6 weeks; healing may take up to 12 months
  • Curettage is needed if the x-rays show no healing after conservative management.

The following X-ray and MRI images show Brodie's abscess of the radius in a patient.

The differentiating features of each of the given conditions are as follows:

Condition Age group Radiographic findings
Brodie's abscess

Children, adolescents

 Lytic lesion with dense sclerotic rim, minimal periosteal reaction
Osteosarcoma (Option A)

Bimodal: Children and adolescents, 70-80 years

Rapidly progressive tumor

 Periosteal reaction leading to sunray appearance and Codman triangle

Osteoclastoma (Option B)

 20-40 years (unlikely in children) Lytic lesion with thin sclerotic rim, minimal periosteal reaction
Ewing's sarcoma (Option D) 10-20 years Diaphyseal mass and periosteal reaction with onion-peel appearance

questions.text: Ligasure can seal vessels up to:
questions.solution:
• Ligasure is a vessel sealing system that is used in both open and laparoscopic surgery.
  • It fuses the vessel walls to create a permanent seal and is in wide use in gynaecology, colorectal surgery, and urology.
  • It uses monopolar technology that uses the body’s collagen and elastin to both seal and divide.
  • Ligasure can seal vessels up to 7 mm in diameter, with an average seal time of 2-4 sec, as well as pedicles, tissue bundles and lymphatics.

questions.text: The subcostal angle during pregnancy is
questions.solution:
The subcostal angle during pregnancy is 105 degrees.

  • Anatomic changes in the respiratory system
  • Elevation of diaphragm by 4cm
  • Transverse diameter of chest increases by 2 cm
  • Subcostal angle increases from 68 to 103
  • Chest circumference increases by 5-7 cm

questions.text: Which of the following is not a stage in the classical disease process of chronic gastritis?
questions.solution:
• Gastric metaplasia is not a stage of chronic gastritis.
  • Stages of chronic gastritis are:
  • Superficial gastritis – In this early phase, the lamina propria of the surface mucosa is affected by inflammatory changes. The gastric glands are separated by infiltration and edema.
  • Atrophic gastritis – In this next stage, there is progressive distortion and destruction of the gastric glands due to the inflammatory infiltrates.
  • Gastric atrophy – This final stage is characterized by loss of glandular structures and thinning of mucosa.

questions.text: Foot complications in DM are due to all except
questions.solution:
The factors for increased incidence of foot complications in DM are due to:

  • Option b Neuropathy

Autonomic neuropathy results in anhidrosis and altered superficial blood flow in the foot that promote drying of skin and fissure formation.

  • Option c microangiopathic changes

Neuropathy is a microvascular complication that leads to abnormal foot muscle mechanics, and structural changes in the foot (hammertoe, claw toe deformity, prominent metatarsal heads, charcoat joint).

  • Option d macroangiopathy

Peripheral arterial disease is a macroangiopathic complication which leads to ischemia in the lower extremity and an increased risk of ulceration in diabetic patients. 

  • Abnormal foot biomechanics
  • Poor wound healing

Grades of diabetic foot ulcers

  • Grade 0 skin intact, bony deformities produce "foot at risk"
  • Grade 1 localized, superficial ulcer
  • Grade 2 ulcer deep to tendon, bone, ligament or joint
  • Grade 3 deep abscess, osteomyelitis
  • Grade 4 gangrene of toes or forefoot
  • Grade 5 gangrene

 

Complications of Diabetes Mellitus

Microvascular Macrovascular
  • Eye disease
  • Retinopathy (Non-proliferative/ proliferative)
  • Macular edema
  • Coronary heart disease
  • Peripheral arterial disease
  • Cerebrovascular disease  
  • Neuropathy
  • Sensory and motor (mono and polyneuropathy)
  • Autonomic
  • Nephropathy

questions.text: The drug that is used for the treatment of the axillary hyperhidrosis acts on which of the following site?
questions.solution:
The drug that is used in treatment of Axillary hyperhidrosis is Botulinium toxin which acts on site D by inhibiting the release of Acetyl choline into the synaptic cleft.

Two toxins interfere with cholinergic transmission by affecting release of ACh:

  • botulinum toxin inhibits release
  • black widow spider toxin induces massive release and depletion.

Botulinium toxin:

By preventing the release of ACh into the synaptic cleft, it decreases the stimulation of NM receptors and muscle contractions.

Used in the treatment of:

  • Hemifacial spasm
  • Achalasia
  • Torticolis
  • Strabismus
  • Blepharospasm
  • Cosmetological removal of wrinkles

questions.text: Bilateral large retinoblastoma tumors indicate which of the following modalities in its initial treatment?
questions.solution:
• In retinoblastoma with large tumors, chemoreduction is done first followed by local management or enucleation/exenteration.
  • In chemoreduction, VEC regimen is used which includes vincristine, etoposide and carboplatin.
  • Extra-orbital extension usually indicates the need for exenteration.
  • Local management includes laser therapy and cryotherapy.
  • The following table gives the international classification of retinoblastoma.
Group Prognosis for maintenance of sight Features
1 Very favourable
  • Solitary tumor, <4DD, at or behind equator
  • Multiple tumors, all <4DD, all at or behind the equator
2 Favourable
  • Solitary tumor, 4–10 DD, at or behind the equator
  • Multiple tumors, all 4–10DD all behind the equator
3 Possible
  • Any lesion anterior to equator
  • Solitary tumor, >10DD behind equator
4 Unfavorable
  • Multiple tumors, some >10 DD
  • Any lesion extending anteriorly to ora serrata

  • Massive tumors involving more than one half of retina
  • Vitreous seeding

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indicator used in the Global Hunger Index?
questions.solution:
• Global Hunger Index (GHI) uses three indicators undernourishment, children underweight and child mortality.

The Global hunger Index is calculated as follows : 

  1. GHI = (PUN +CUW + CM)/3

with GHI : Global Hunger Index 

PUN : proportion of the population that is undernourished (in%) 

CUW : prevalence of underweight in children under five (in%) 

CM : proportion of children dying before the age of five (in%)

  • The result lies on a scale from 0 to 100, with 0 meaning no hunger and 100 being the worst score.
  • In 2016, India’s GHI was 28.5.
  • The GHI is given by the International Food Policy Research Institute.

questions.text: Which of the following is not part of the surgical audit process?

choices.text: Identify the body of evidence and current standards

questions.solution:
• Audit is a process used by clinicians who seek to improve patient care.
  • The process involves comparing aspects of care (structure, process and outcome) against explicit criteria and defined standards.
  • The following are the essential steps of a surgical audit:
    • Define the audit question
    • Identify the body of evidence and current standards
    • Design the audit to measure performance against agreed standards.
    • Measure over an agreed interval.
    • Analyze results and compare performance.
    • Undertake gap analysis.
    • Re-audit

questions.text: All the following statements are true about desmoid tumor except:

choices.text: It is also called as aggressive fibromatosis
Can be associated with Gardner syndrome
Biopsy is needed to establish the diagnosis
Recurrence is not common after surgery

questions.solution:
• Desmoid tumors are prone to recurrence and thus, completeness of resection is an important prognostic factor.
  • Desmoids can be associated with Gardner syndrome and familial adenomatous polyposis syndrome.
  • Biopsy is needed for diagnosis. Immuno-histochemistry can clarify a difficult diagnosis.
  • They stain positive for beta-catenin, actin and vimentin.
  • Optimal treatment is considered to be resection of the tumor with wide margin of normal tissue.
  • They are radio-responsive.
  • Tamoxifen, NSAIDs are also used in the treatment.

questions.text: Womb stone appearance is seen in which type of degeneration
questions.solution: Calcific degeneration of a fibroid involves deposition of calcium carbonate and phosphate within the tumor. When whole of the tumor is converted into a calcified mass, it is called womb stone.

questions.text: A 35 year old male presented with a chronic non-healing ulcer over the leg. He gives history of  gall stones, severe pain the digits of hands and feet as well as an episode of salmonella osteomyelitis. He was immunised earlier because the physician told him that he has greater chance of infection caused by capsulated organisms. His peripheral smear is shown in the figure. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The peripheral smear shows sickle cells, target cells and polychromasia suggestive of sickle cell anaemia.

  • Sickle cell disease is caused by a point mutation in the sixth codon of β-globin that leads to the replacement of a glutamate residue with a valine residue.
  • HbS molecules stack into polymers when deoxygenated. With continued deoxygenation HbS molecules assemble into long needle-like fibers within red cells, producing a distorted sickle or holly-leaf shape.
  • Polymerization of deoxygenated hemoglobin, leading to red cell distortion, hemolytic anemia, microvascular obstruction, and ischemic tissue damage.
  • The major pathologic manifestations— Chronic hemolysis, microvascular occlusions, and tissue damage.
  • Peripheral blood demonstrates -  Irreversibly sickled cells, reticulocytosis, and target cells, which result from red cell dehydration with Howell-Jolly bodies.
  • Hyperplastic bone marrow-àExpansion of the marrow -àbone resorption and secondary new bone formation, -  “crewcut” on x-ray studies.
  • Increased breakdown of hemoglobin -  pigment gallstones and hyperbilirubinemia
  • Early childhood- Splenomegaly,  Adolesence- fibrosis, and progressive shrinkage, - autosplenectomy
  • Priapism affects up to 45% of males. Leg ulcers may be present.
  • Stroke and retinopathy leading to loss of visual acuity and even blindness
  • Vaso-occlusive crises,or pain crises -  episodes of hypoxic injury and infarction that cause severe pain in the affected region - hand-foot syndrome or dactylitis
  • Acute chest syndrome- vaso-occlusive crisis involving the lungs with fever, cough, chest pain, and pulmonary infiltrates.
  • Sequestration crises – In children with intact spleens. Massive entrapment of sickle red cells leads to rapid splenic enlargement, hypovolemia, and sometimes shock.
  • Aplastic crises - infection of red cell progenitors by parvovirus B19, which causes a transient cessation of erythropoiesis and a sudden worsening of the anemia
  • Increased susceptibility to infection with encapsulated organisms is another threat. due to altered splenic function
  • Pneumococcus pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae septicemia and meningitis are common, particularly in children, but can be reduced by vaccination and prophylactic antibiotics.
  • Diagnosis - Mixing a blood sample with metabisulfite, which induces sickling of red cells if HbS is present.
  • Hemoglobin electrophoresis is also used to demonstrate the presence of HbS.

questions.text: Which type of sensory receptor provides information about the force of muscle contraction?
questions.solution:
Golgi tendon organ provides information about force of contraction of muscle.

Golgi tendon organ:

  • It is present in series with the muscle fibres
  • They are stimulated by both passive stretch and active contraction of the muscle.
  • The threshold of the Golgi tendon organs is low
  • Golgi tendon organ thus functions as a transducer in a feedback circuit that regulates muscle force in a manner analogous to the spindle feedback circuit that regulates muscle length.
  • The interaction of spindle discharge, tendon organ discharge, and reciprocal innervation determines the rate of discharge of α-motor neurons.

questions.text: Relationship of neurovascular bundle from above downward in the intercostal space is
questions.solution: In the costal groove, from superior to inferior is the posterior intercostal vein, posterior intercostal artery and intercostal nerve (VAN goes down)

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is not present in the mitochondrial matrix?
questions.solution:
ATP synthase is located on the inner mitochondrial membrane, not mitochondrial matrix.

Note: In contrast to the other enzymes of citric acid cycle, succinate dehydrogenase is bound to the inner surface of inner mitochondrial membrane. Succinate dehydrogenase functions as complex II of electron transport chain.

Related Pearl: Electron transport chain: components and its inhibitors

questions.text: Which of the toxins produced by clostridium species is the basis of Nagler's reaction?
questions.solution:
α-toxin produced by Clostridium perfringens forms the basis of Nagler's reaction.

The α-toxin of C.perfringens has lecithinase activity. When C.perfringens is grown on a media containing egg yolk with the α-antitoxin spread on one half of the plate, colonies on the other half without the antitoxin will be surrounded by a zone of opacity. There will be no opacity around the colonies on the half of the plate with the antitoxin due to the specific neutralization of α-toxin. This is known as Nagler's reaction.

questions.text: Chalcosis is seen with heavily alloyed variants of:
questions.solution:
• Chalcosis is seen as an ocular reaction to retention of heavily alloyed variants of copper in the eye.
  • Features of this condition include, grayish or golden brown discoloration of peripheral cornea, sunflower cataract and golden plaques at posterior pole of retina that reflect light with a metallic sheen.
  • This is a milder condition than when pure copper is retained in the eye after a penetrating injury which can result in endophthalmitis and pthisis bulbi.

questions.text: Highest thiamine content amongst the following foods is in:
questions.solution:
• Black sesame seeds or gingelly seeds contain almost around 1.01 mg of thiamine in 100g.
  • Almonds, groundnuts and Bengal gram dhal are also good sources of vitamin B1 but contain lower amounts of it as compared to gingelly seeds.

questions.text: Pinna develops from
questions.solution:
• Tragus develops from the tubercle of the first arch while the rest of the pinna develops from the remaining five tubercles of the second arch.
  • Faulty fusion between the first and the second arch tubercles causes preauricular sinus or cyst, which is commonly seen between the tragus and crus of helix.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy starts seizing while playing catch with his father. He is immediately brought to the casualty. On examination, blood pressure in the upper extremity measured as 200/140 mm Hg and femoral pulses were not palpable. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Here, the diagnosis is coarctation of the aorta because the classic sign of coarctation of the aorta is a disparity in pulsation and blood pressure in the arms and legs (as seen in this patient). The femoral, popliteal, posterior tibial, and dorsalis pedis pulses are weak (or absent in up to 40% of patients), in contrast to the bounding pulses of the arms and carotid vessels. Seizure is a complication secondary to systemic hypertension since untreated coarctation can increase the risk for intracranial hemorrhage and hypertensive encephalopathy.

The most common site of coarctation of the aorta is distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery near the insertion of ligamentum arteriosum (juxtaductal coarctation).

DDx: Takayasu arteritis is a chronic vasculitis of unknown etiology, predominantly affecting women with an age of onset that is usually between 10 and 40 years. The disease primarily affects the aorta and its primary branches.

questions.text: Which of the following brain tumours show calcification?
questions.solution:
All the tumors mentioned in options show calcification. Oligodendroglioma shows calcification in 90% of the patients. Pediatric craniopharyngiomas are known to have calcification.

Brain tumors which show calcification and hemorrhagic lesions:

Brain tumours which show calcification are:

Oligodendroglioma

Choroid plexus papilloma

Ependymoma

Craniopharyngioma

Astrocytoma Meningioma 
Brain tumors with hemorrhagic lesions:

GBM (grade 4 glioma)

Oligodendroglioma

Metastatses: Melanoma, Lung, Breast

questions.text: Systematic desensitisation is useful for which of the following?
questions.solution:
Systematic desensitisation is one of the behavioural therapy techniques used in OCD. It is the least effective form of treatment for OCD.

Behaviour therapy is wherein the maladaptive behaviour is corrected.

The various types for bringing about behaviour modification is:

  • Systematic desensitization –this is based on the principle of reciprocal inhibition wherein the person is exposed to the stimulus and then relaxation techniques are used to calm the patient.

           Gradually increasing dose of the stimulus is given and this will lead to reduced response

  • Therapeutic graded exposure is similar to systematic desensitization but doesn’t involve the relaxation techniques
  • Exposure and response prevention – is used in phobias and OCD, where the stimulus is exposed but the response is prevented
  • Flooding
  • Aversion technique
  • Operant conditioning

questions.text: Bony ankylosis is seen in _________.
questions.solution:
Bony ankylosis (fusion of bones) is seen in the following conditions:

  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Septic arthritis
  • Tuberculosis of the spine
  • Rheumatoid arthritis (later stages)

Treatment of bony ankylosis: Displacement osteotomy

Note: Tuberculosis of joints everywhere else in the body results only in fibrous ankylosis except in the spine where it causes bony ankylosis.

Image: X-ray image of septic arthritis of the hip.

Note: According to Ebnezar's textbook of orthopedics, RA shows fibrous ankylosis in early-stage and bony ankylosis in late-stage.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of facial melanosis?
questions.solution:
Melasma or chloasma faciei is the most common cause of facial melanosis. 

The following image shows a female with melasma over the malar region.

 

Melasma is the most common cause of facial melanosis that manifests as hyperpigmented macules on the face. It is exacerbated by sun exposure and oral contraceptive pills. The condition is predominantly seen in females. 

Melasma presents as hypermelanosis of the upper lip, malar regions, forehead, and chin. There may also be darkening of the nipples, linea alba, and groin. The lesions are usually bilateral and symmetrical.  In a pregnant woman, melasma is called chloasma (also known as mask of pregnancy). Chloasma is very common in the 3rd trimester of pregnancy.

Treatment 

  • First-line - Sun protection, changing oral contraceptives to low estrogen formulation, or triple therapy with topical hydroquinone, tretinoin, and corticosteroid cream.
  • Second-line - Chemical peels, Azelaic acid alone or in combination with tretinoin.
  • Third line - Laser therapy, pulsed light therapy, dermabrasion, topical liquiritin, topical rucinol, kojic acid, and hydroquinone.

Related Pearl: Key Chart to help differentiate lesions on face

Key Chart to help Differentiate Lesions on face

questions.text: While examining a man who is accused of rape, you find the presence of smegma on his corona glandis. Which of the following can be inferred from this finding?

choices.text: The person has engaged in sexual act recently
The person has not engaged in sexual act in last 24 hours
The person has not engaged in sexual act in last 48 hours
The person has not engaged in sexual act in last 1 week

questions.solution:
The presence of smegma on the corona glandis indicates that the person has not engaged in a sexual act in the last 24 hours.

Smegma requires about 24 hours to collect. It gets removed by bathing or washing or intercourse. The absence indicates sexual activity might have been performed in the last 24 hours as it gets rubbed off during intercourse. The presence of smegma absolutely negates the possibility of complete penetration.

questions.text: All of the following are true about paralytic strabismus except:
questions.solution:
• There is no ambylopia in paralytic strabismus but diplopia is present.
  • Other features are restriction of ocular movements, false orientation, head tilt, vertigo and squint.
  • Paralytic strabismus (incomitant strabismus) is almost always due to pathology that causes restriction of extra-ocular movements.
  • It is mostly acquired or related to traumatic events.
  • In this, primary deviation < secondary deviation.
  • There is normal visual acuity in paralytic squint.
  • Park 3-step test and Bielschowsky head tilt test are used to identify the affected muscle in this condition.
  • Treatment is aimed at the underlying pathology and in some cases, once the deviation has stabilized, surgery is recommended.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about perinatal mortality rate?

choices.text: Crown heel length of at least 35cms
Deaths within first week of life included

questions.solution:
Perinatal mortality rate (PMR) includes stillbirths which are categorized as late fetal deaths.

The perinatal mortality rate is a significant indicator in the evaluation of obstetric and neonatal care given before and around the time of birth. It is calculated as given below to enable international comparisons. Late fetal death or stillbirth is the death of a fetus that weighs 1000 grams or more (corresponds to 28 weeks of gestation). Early neonatal death is the death of a fetus from birth to the first 7 days of life (Option D).

The following parameters must be considered while calculating PMR:

  • Babies chosen for inclusion in the PMR should be those above a minimum birth weight of 1000g. (Option A)
  • If birth weight is not available, then gestational age must be at least 28 weeks.
  • If both of the above are not available, then the crown heel length must be at least 35 cm. (Option C)

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with atrial fibrillation complains of sudden onset weakness of the right lower limb, with urinary and faecal incontinence. MRI shows an ischaemic stroke involving the left anterior cerebral artery. Which of the following features would you not expect to see in this patient?
questions.solution:
Prosopagnosia, also called face blindness, is the inability to recognize faces including one's own image. This occurs due to occipitotemporal lobe damage, seen in posterior cerebral artery (PCA) strokes involving cortical branch occlusion.
It is not seen in anterior cerebral artery strokes. 

The anterior cerebral artery (ACA) supplies parts of the frontal lobe, corpus callosum, paracentral lobule, and other deeper structures.

Signs and symptoms of ACA occlusion and structures involved:

  • Urinary incontinence, fecal incontinence
  • Paratonic rigidity
  • Abulia (Akinetic mutism), lack of spontaneity, slowness
  • Gait impairment
  • Paralysis of contralateral foot and leg
  • Paresis of the contralateral arm
  • Cortical sensory loss over the contralateral lower limb
  • Dyspraxia of left limbs, tactile aphasia in left limbs.
