questions.text: What is the approximate fetal weight , if height of uterus is 35cm above the pubic symphysis and station of head is –2?
questions.solution:
The fetal weight in the above case is 3.5Kg.

Estimation of fetal weight :

  • Fetal growth velocity is
    • maximum (26.9 g/day) over the 32–36 weeks of pregnancy
    • It declines gradually to 24 g/day over the 36–40 weeks of gestation.
    • Individual fetal growth varies considerably
  • Johnson’s formula
    • If station of head is below the level of the ischial spine
    • [Height of uterus above pubic symphysis (in cm)-11] x 155 in grams
    • If station of head is above the level of the ischial spine
    • [Height of uterus above pubic symphysis (in cm)-12] x 155 in grams
  • Sonography
    • Shepard’s formula: Log 10 EFW (g) = 1.2508 + (0.166 × BPD) + 0.046 × AC) – (0.002646 × AC × BPD)
    • Hadlock’s formula: Log 10 EFW (g) = 1.3596 – 0.00386 (AC × FL) + 0.0064 (HC) + 0.00061 (BPD × AC) + 0.0425 (AC) + 0.174 (FL)

In the above case, fetal weight can be estimated using Johnson formula.

In the above case, height of uterus is 35cm, station is –2 and hence fetal weight is: [35-12] x 155 = 3565 grams = 3.5Kg

questions.text: The specific marker for Langerhans cell histiocytosis is?
questions.solution:
Immunohistochemical markers for langerhans cell histiocytosis are :

  • CD1a
  • HLADR
  • CD 68
  • S100
  • Langerin

 

  • CD 5 is expressed on almost all T cells, B cells in bone marrow, B cells in peritoneal and pleural cavities and some B cells in mantle zone of spleen and lymph nodes.
  • CD 22 is expressed on B cells (considered a pan B cell antigen), dendritic cells and basophils
  • CD 30 is expressed on granulocytes, plasma cells , Activated B, T and NK cells, monocytes and decidua.

Langerhans cell histiocytosis

  • Langerhans cells have abundant, often vacuolated cytoplasm and vesicular nuclei containing linear grooves or folds.
  • Birbeck granules in the cytoplasm is characteristic- Tennis racket-like appearance which contain the protein langerin.
  • Normal epidermal Langerhans cells express CCR6, their neoplastic counterparts express both CCR6 and CCR7.
  • Multifocal multisystem Langerhans cell histiocytosis (Letterer-Siwe disease) - Cutaneous lesions resembling a seborrheic eruption, concurrent hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, pulmonary lesions, destructive osteolytic bone lesions, anemia, thrombocytopenia and a predisposition to recurrent infections, such as otitis media and mastoiditis.
  • Unifocal and multifocal unisystem Langerhans cell histiocytosis (eosinophilic granuloma) -Proliferations of Langerhans cells admixed with variable numbers of eosinophils, lymphocytes, plasma cells, and neutrophils. Sites- Medullary cavities of bones, most commonly the calvarium, ribs, and femur, skin, lungs, or stomach.
  • Multifocal unisystem disease - young children with multiple erosive bony masses that sometimes expand into adjacent soft tissue.
  • Involvement of the posterior pituitary stalk of the hypothalamus- Diabetes insipidus The combination of calvarial bone defects, diabetes insipidus, and exophthalmos is referred to as the Hand-Schüller-Christian triad.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl was brought to the OPD by her mother who is concerned about her significant increase in height compared to her classmates in the last 2 years. On examination, the girl shows breast development corresponding to B2 Tanner stage. What is the most common brain lesion causing this condition?
questions.solution:
Hypothalamic hamartoma, a neuronal migration defect, is the most common cause of organic central precocious puberty. The onset of breast development before the age of 8 years in females and onset of testicular development (>4 mL) before the age of 9 years in males is suggestive of central precocious puberty. 

It is a congenital malformation that consists of ectopically located neural tissue characterised by-

  • Early-onset of puberty
  • Seizures associated with unnatural crying or laughing episodes are known as gelastic seizures.

Tuberculous meningitis, tuberous sclerosis, and astrocytomas can also cause central precocious puberty.

questions.text: What is the rationale for choosing an inhaled anesthetic with the lowest MAC value?
questions.solution:
A drug with the lowest MAC would have the highest potency.

The minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) value of an inhaled anesthetic is a measure of the potency of the anesthetic agent.

Least potent: nitrous oxide (MAC-104%). 1 MAC with nitrous oxide is practically impossible and thus it is always combined with other agents.

Most potent: methoxyflurane (MAC-0.16%) > trilene (MAC-0.2%), both of which are obsolete now.

Among the inhaled agents in clinical use, halothane is the most potent.

Related Pearl: Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC)

Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) is the minimum concentration of an inhaled anesthetic at 1 atm of pressure that prevents skeletal muscle movement in response to a surgical incision in 50% of patients. 

MAC of inhaled anesthetics

Anesthetic Agents

MAC (Potency)

Blood-gas coefficient (Solubility)
Halothane 0.75  2.4
Isoflurane 1.2 1.4 
Enflurane 1.7 1.9 
Sevoflurane 2 0.65 
Desflurane 6 0.42 
Nitrous oxide 104 0.47 

MAC is an indicator of potency. The lower the MAC, the higher is the potency.

questions.text: How many sizes of the following 1st generation IUD are available?
questions.solution:
• Lippes Loop is a 1st generation IUD that comes in four sizes – A, B, C and D.
  • It is an S shaped device, usually made of polyethylene.

questions.text: A health care worker who had an accidental needle stick injury from a HIV positive and asymptomatic patient 36 hours ago, has come for receiving post exposure prophylaxis. Which of the following is the preferred regimen?
questions.solution:
Recommended Post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) is a three drug regimen which includes Lamivudine 300mg, Tenofovir 300mg and Dolutegravir 50mg. A regimen for post - exposure prophylaxis for HIV with two anti retroviral (ARV) drugs is effective, but three drugs are preferred. The PEP must be initiated ideally within 2 hours and certainly within 72 hours. WHO recommended PEP regimen :

        Drugs combination   Recommendation for PEP         Duration
Tenofovir (TDF) 300 mg + Lamivudine(3TC) 300 mg + Dolutegravir (DTG) 50mg          Once daily          4 weeks

DTG is recommended as the preferred third drug for HIV post-exposure prophylaxis.

Related Pearl: 2021 NACO Guidelines on Post-exposure Prophylaxis (PEP) for HIV

Exposure Codes

  • EC1: Mild exposure: mucous membrane/non-intact skin with small volumes/eyes or mucous membrane or subcutaneous injections following small-bore needles
  • EC2: Moderate exposure: mucous membrane/non-intact skin with large volumes or percutaneous superficial exposure with a solid needle
  • EC3: Severe exposure: percutaneous with large volume by hollow needle, deep puncture

HIV Source Codes

  • SC 1- HIV +ve, asymptomatic, CD count high, low viral load
  • SC 2- HIV +ve, symptomatic, CD count low, high viral load
  • SC unknown: HIV status unknown

Recommended PEP regimens

1) Adolescents and Adults (>10 years of age and >30 kg weight): Tenofovir 300 mg + Lamivudine 300 mg + Dolutegravir 50 mg

2) Children (>6 years of age and >20 kg weight): Zidovudine (dosage as per weight band) + Lamivudine (dosage as per weight band) + Dolutegravir 50 mg

  • PEP must be initiated ideally within 2 hours and certainly within 72 hours.
  • Duration of PEP: 28 days/4weeks

questions.text: What is the investigation shown below
questions.solution:
• ERCP stands for endoscopic retrograde cholangio-pancreatography.
  • It involves the use of a side viewing endoscope which is passed through the pylorus of stomach into the second part of duodenum to visualise the papilla.
  • This is then cannulated, and dye is injected into the pancreatic or bile duct to visualise the pancreatic or biliary tree. It can be therapeutic or diagnostic.
  • Option A -  MRCP stands for Magnetic Retrograde Cholangio-pancreatography. It is a non invasive procedure using MRI. Therapeutic procedures cannot be done.
  • Note: To know whether the given investigation is ERCP or MRCP, look for the endoscope. If endoscope is visible in the picture it is always an ERCP, whereas in MRCP there will be no endoscope.
  • Option B – EUS is endoscopic ultrasound. It combines the traditional mucosal image with a separate ultrasound view that clearly depicts the intestinal layers.
  • Option D – PTC is percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography. It is a way of examining the bile duct system in the liver. This procedure is done under local anesthesia by a radiologist.

questions.text: Most common site of venous thrombosis is
questions.solution:
Most common site of venous thrombosis is veins of the lower extremities.

Venous thrombosis (phlebothrombosis) -They form in the sluggish venous circulation

  • Tend to contain more enmeshed red cells (and relatively few platelets) and are therefore known as red, or stasis, thrombi
  • Firm, are focally attached to the vessel wall, and contain lines of Zahn, features that help distinguish them from postmortem clots
  • The veins of the lower extremities are most commonly involved (90% of cases); however, may also develop in upper extremities, periprostatic plexus, ovarian and periuterine veins dural sinuses, portal vein, or hepatic vein.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with end-stage renal disease was planning to undergo hemodialysis. An arteriovenous fistula was created on his forearm. This procedure is done mainly to achieve a minimum venous flow rate of:
questions.solution:
The process of dialysis occurs over many hours and requires considerable flow rates of 250-500 mL/minute.

As no vein in the peripheral limbs has such high flow, a surgical procedure (AV fistulas) is necessary to create such a system.

Two types of arteriovenous fistulas:

  • The radial artery is anastomosed to the cephalic vein in the wrist (most common)
  • The brachial artery is anastomosed to the cephalic vein at the elbow

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with complaints of sudden painless loss of vision in the left eye since yesterday. She also gives a history of temporal headaches, myalgias, and pain in the jaw while chewing. Examination of the left eye reveals a visual acuity of HM+ and an RAPD. Fundus examination of the left eye shows cattle trucking of blood within the retinal veins on applying gentle pressure. Which of the following is the likely cause of fundal findings?

choices.text: Non- ischemic central retinal venous occlusion

questions.solution:
A 52-year-old woman temporal headaches, myalgias and pain in the jaw while chewing likely has giant cell arteritis (GCA). Given that she has sudden painless monocular loss of vision with RAPD and points to a diagnosis of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO).

GCA is the most common primary vasculitis in adults. It is a risk factor for the development of CRAO. CRAO occurs due to obstruction of the retinal artery at the level of lamina cribrosa. When obstruction to the blood flow is not complete, the flow may be partially restored. Thus, gentle pressure upon the globe may break the column of venous blood into red beads separated by clear interspaces. This gives the characteristic 'cattle truck' appearance.

Option A: Ischemic CRVO shows a characteristic "splashed tomato sauce" appearance on fundoscopy. 

Option C: Non-Ischemic CRVO does not present with such a severe loss of visual acuity.

Option D: Branched retinal artery occlusion presents with hemifield visual defects.

questions.text: Which level does the structure marked as X in the image lie at?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the image is the fundus of the gallbladder. It lies at the level of L1 in the transpyloric plane.

The tip of the ninth costal cartilage in the transpyloric plane, near the junction of the linea semilunaris with the costal margin is used to identify the fundus of the gall bladder. 

The transpyloric plane is an imaginary plane that lies midway between the suprasternal notch and the upper border of the pubic symphysis. Posteriorly, this plane intersects the lower half of the body of the first lumbar vertebra. Anteriorly, it intersects the costal margin at the ninth costal cartilage.

Related Pearl: Abdominal planes and their landmarks

Planes that divide the abdomen into 9 regions are:

  • Horizontal planes 
    • At the level of L3 - Subcostal plane (between 10th costal cartilages). It corresponds to the 3rd part of the duodenum
    • At the level of L5 - Transtubercular plane (between tubercles of iliac crests). It corresponds to the origin of inferior vena cava. 
  • Vertical planes (paramedian or lateral planes)
    • From mid-clavicular point to mid-inguinal point on both sides 

The nine regions of the abdomen include:

  • Right hypochondriac, epigastric, left hypochondriac
  • Right lumbar, umbilical (central), left lumbar
  • Right iliac, hypogastric (suprapubic), left iliac

Other planes and angles in the abdomen are:

  • Transpyloric (Addison's) plane - passes midway between the suprasternal notch and the upper border of the pubic symphysis.
  • Supracristal plane - passes through the highest point of the iliac crest on both sides. It corresponds to the level of the L4 body or L4/5 disc and its spinous process. It is an important landmark when performing a lumbar puncture or spinal injection. The bifurcation of the abdominal aorta lies approximately in this plane.
  • The plane of the pubic crest - passes through the upper border of the pubic symphysis. In supine, this plane intersects the tip of the coccyx and the femoral head.
  • Renal angle - between the 12th rib and the outer border of erector spinae muscle. The lower border of normal kidneys may occasionally be felt here. 
  • Lumbar triangle of Petit - formed below by the iliac crest, anteriorly by external oblique, and posteriorly by latissimus dorsi. Lumbar hernia can occur here.

questions.text: All of the following CSF findings are present in tuberculous meningitis, except:
questions.solution:
Glucose levels are decreased in CSF in  tuberculous meningitis. The CSF in TB has a cobweb appearance and shows lymphocytic pleocytosis with increased protein and decreased glucose. Acid fast bacilli might be seen.

Characteristic CSF findings of TBM include the following:

  1. Lymphocytic-predominant pleiocytosis. Total white cell counts are usually between 100 and 500 cells/μL. Very early in the disease, lower counts and neutrophil predominance may be present.
  2. Elevated protein levels, typically between 100 and 500 mg/dL.
  3. Low glucose, usually less than 45 mg/dL or CSF: plasma ratio <0.5.

questions.text: The following shows a transverse B mode image of the right common femoral vein, right common femoral artery and great saphenous vein. What is this sign called?
questions.solution:
• The appearance of common femoral artery, long saphenous vein and common femoral vein on B mode transverse ultrasound is known as Mickey Mouse sign.
  • Option A – Saphenous eye is transverse B mode view of long saphenous vein in fascial compartments of the thigh.
  • Option C – Panda sign or periorbital ecchymosis is seen in head injury.
  • Option D – Orphan Annie eye or nuclei is seen in papillary carcinoma of thyroid showing large nuclei cleared out in the centre with powdery chromatin marginated to the periphery.

questions.text: SSRI’s should be carefully used in the young for the management of depression due to increase in
questions.solution: Somatic symptoms of depression improve faster than psychological symptoms when a patient is started on SSRI’s and hence patient have energy to act on their thoughts which can include thoughts of deliberate self-harm and suicide. Hence Cognitive behavioural therapy should be started simultaneously in patients with depression.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common intraocular presentation of lymphoma?
questions.solution:
• The most common presentation of intraocular lymphoma is non-resolving uveitis with decreasing vision.
  • Extraocular features include lid and orbital deposits.
  • Chorioretinal scars are seen in sickle cell anemia.
  • Retinal edema is an intraocular presentation seen in leukemia alongside hemorrhages.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with posterior hip dislocation. Which of the following reduction methods is not used for the management of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Kocher’s maneuver is used for the management of shoulder dislocation. 

Reduction of hip dislocation (closed or open) should ideally be performed within 6 hours to prevent osteonecrosis of the hip joint.

Methods of closed reduction for posterior hip dislocation are:

1. Allis maneuver- traction applied opposite to the direction of deformity

 

2. Stimson maneuver- downward pressure to the flexed knee (patient is prone and at the edge of the table)

 

3. Bigelow maneuver- longitudinal traction with pressure on ASIS to stabilize the pelvis

 

4. East Baltimore lift maneuver- anterior force on the flexed knee (doctor's and assistant's place hands below the flexed knee)

questions.text: A 17-year-old presents to you with complaints of passing loose stools. Given below are the findings of his stool microscopy. Infection with which of the following bacteria would you consider in your differential diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clip shows darting motility which is seen in Vibrio cholerae and Campylobacter jejuni. Thus, among the given options, infection with C. jejuni should be considered as a differential diagnosis in this case.

Campylobacter jejuni possesses a single polar flagellum, hence it exhibits darting motility.

Shigella dysenteriae is a non-motile organism.

questions.text: Administering epinephrine to a person on which of the following drugs will lead to the vasomotor reversal of Dale?
questions.solution:
The vasomotor reversal of Dale seen on administering epinephrine is seen when an alpha blocker like phentolamine has been previously administered.

Rapid IV injection of adrenaline produces a marked increase in both systolic as well as diastolic BP because at high concentrations, α response predominates and vasoconstriction occurs. As the concentration declines, adrenaline is not able to act on α receptors but continues to act on β2 receptors.

When an α blocker has been given and then adrenaline is injected, only a fall in BP instead of an initial rise is seen, an effect first described by Dale and hence called vasomotor reversal of Dale. This is due to adrenaline's action only on β2 receptors, which are not blocked by phentolamine.

Among the given options, only phentolamine is an α blocker, which abolishes the pressor effect of the epinephrine and produces vasodilation, leading to a vasomotor reversal of Dale.

questions.text: If a person’s height is 178 cms, calculate his ideal body weight using the Broca index
questions.solution:
• According to the Broca index, if the person’s height is 178 cms, his ideal weight would be 78 kgs.
  • Broca index is given by height (in cms) minus 100.
  • It is a measure of body weight and gives the ideal weight for a person for his/her height.

questions.text: Middle ear transformer ratio is
questions.solution:
• Effective vibratory area of TM: 45 mm2
  • Footplate area: 3.2 mm2
  • Areal ratio: 14:1
  • Lever ratio (ossicles): 1.3:1
  • Total transformer ratio 14 × 1.3 = 18.2:1
  • Say 18:1

Note: This is a controversial topic. There are two different schools of thought regarding the effective vibratory area of the tympanic membrane. 
i) One considers the effective area of the tympanic membrane to be 45mm2 giving a total ratio of 18:1
ii) The second one by Wever and Lawrence considers the effective area to be 55mm2, giving a total ratio of 22:1.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is not caused by the spiral-shaped genus of bacteria represented in the following photomicrograph?
questions.solution:
• The image shown is of Treponema pallidum which belongs to the genus of spiral-shaped bacteria called Treponema. They come under the family of Spirochetes.
  • Diseases caused by Treponema bacteria are pinta (T. carateum), bejel or endemic syphilis (T. pallidum endemicum), yaws (T. pertenue) and syphilis (T. pallidum pallidum).
  • The first three from the above diseases are collectively called endemic treponematoses.
  • Kyasanur forest disease is caused by a virus, called KFD virus, which belongs to group flaviviridae.

questions.text: Nitrogen narcosis is due to:

choices.text: Increased solubility of nitrogen in nerve cell

questions.solution:
N2 has 2 main features:

  • passes through cell membranes very slowly
  • 5 times more soluble in fat than water

Therefore person breathing air under high pressure for a long time – amount of N2 dissolved increases, N2 gets dissolved in fatty substances in the neuronal membranes, and because of its physical effect on altering ionic conductance through membranes, reduces neuronal excitability.

N2 Narcosis (Raptures of deep) have features similar to alcohol intoxication: Euphoria, impairment of mental and motor functions.

questions.text: Rinne positive in both ears and Weber lateralised towards right indicates
questions.solution:
• In Weber's test, sound is lateralized to the worse ear in conductive deafness and to the better ear in sensorineural deafness.
  • Weber lateralised towards right indicates right sided conductive deafness or left side sensorineural deafness. Since Rinne is positive on both ears, conductive deafness is ruled out. So it is left sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.text: The ‘shake test’ is done to check for:

choices.text: Damage to a wet globe thermometer

questions.solution:
• The shake test is done to check for damage to vaccines which are sensitive to freezing temperatures.
  • A frozen vaccine is used as a control vial and the vial suspected to be damaged by freezing is taken as the test vial.
  • Both are shaken after thawing and the rate of sedimentation is compared.
  • If the rate of sedimentation in test vial is slower than the control vial, then it is usable and has not been damaged.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding exenatide?

choices.text: It can be used for the treatment of type 1 diabetes mellitus

questions.solution:
Exenatide is not indicated in type 1 diabetes mellitus.

Exenatide is a GLP-1 analog that acts as an insulin secretagogue. As the beta cells are already destroyed and do not secrete insulin in type 1 diabetes, there is no role of drugs that enhance insulin secretion.

Option A - Exenatide is a GLP-1 analog and it is synthesized from exendin-4 

Option C - It is a peptide and hence has to be administered subcutaneously 

Option D - It increases insulin secretion, decreases glucagon secretion, delays gastric emptying, and reduces food intake

questions.text: A needle is inserted into a particular space to withdraw CSF in an adult as shown below. At which level does this space terminate?
questions.solution:
The procedure shown in the image is a lumbar puncture. In this, the needle is introduced in the subarachnoid space which ends at the lower border of the S2 vertebra.

A lumbar puncture can be done anywhere from L1 to S2 vertebra. Beyond S2, there are only meninges. However, lumbar puncture is most commonly performed at the level of L3 or L4.

questions.text:
BCYE medium is used to culture:

BCYE - Buffered charcoal yeast extract
questions.solution:
BCYE medium (buffered charcoal yeast extract agar) is used to culture Legionella pneumophila.

Legionella pneumophila has fastidious growth requirements and grows on complex media such as  BCYE medium with L-cysteine and antibiotic supplements (e.g., polymyxin B, cefazolin, vancomycin). The charcoal acts as a detoxifying agent. It grows slowly, and the colonies may take 3–6 days to appear.

Other options:

Option A: Leptospira is cultured on EMJH (Ellinghausen, McCullough, Johnson and Harris) medium 

Option B: Bacillus cereus is cultured on PEMBA (Polymyxin pyruvate egg-yolk mannitol–bromothymol blue) agar

Option C: Campylobacter is cultured on Skirrow's, Campy BAP or Butzler's agar.

questions.text: A 10-year-old male child presents with a history of easy bruisiability and hemarthrosis. Investigations revealed normal platelet count and bleeding time, normal PT, and prolonged PTT. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The symptom of hemarthrosis and the investigations are suggestive of a coagulation disorder. Among the given options, hemophilia A is a coagulation disorder, while all the other conditions are platelet disorders.

Bleeding into joints (hemarthrosis) and deep tissues is a feature of coagulation disorders, whereas platelet disorders usually present with mucocutaneous bleeding such as petechiae, purpura, epistaxis, or GI bleed. Prolonged PT/aPTT is a feature of coagulation disorders, while prolonged bleeding time is a feature of platelet disorders.

In the given scenario, normal platelet count and bleeding time exclude platelet disorders. Normal PT indicates normal functioning of the extrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade, and prolonged PTT indicates a defect in the intrinsic pathway.

Hemophilia is an X-linked (recessive) coagulation disorder associated with mutations in factor VIII, affecting the intrinsic pathway. The patients present with easy bruising, significant hemorrhage following trauma and operative procedures, and hemarthroses, but no petechiae. The diagnosis is confirmed by carrying out factor VIII-specific assays. Infusions of recombinant factor VIII are used for treatment. 

Other options:

Option 1: Von Willebrand disease is an autosomal dominant disorder that is associated with qualitative/quantitative defects in the von Willebrand factor (vWF). vWF is a protein necessary for platelet adhesion, platelet aggregation, and stabilization of factor VIII.

Option 3: Bernard-Soulier disease is an autosomal recessive condition that is characterized by the absence of the GpIb receptor necessary for platelet adhesion to the subendothelial collagen. 

Option 4: Glanzmann's thrombasthenia is an autosomal recessive condition that is characterized by the absence of the GpIIb/IIIa receptor necessary for platelet aggregation.

questions.text: Prevalence of a disease can be expressed as the _____ of the incidence and mean duration of the disease.
questions.solution: Prevalence = Incidence x Mean Duration.

questions.text: An alcoholic male patient diagnosed with hollow viscus perforation is taken up for laparotomy. A 2cm sized perforation is seen in the stomach. How can this patient be managed?
questions.solution:
This patient can be managed by a Graham patch repair.

Perforations less than 1 cm can be closed primarily (Option A) and buttressed with omentum. Larger perforations and ulcers with fibrotic edges that cannot be approximated can be managed by an omental patch repair. A tongue of omentum is brought up to cover the ulcer defect and secured with a series of interrupted sutures as shown in the image below.

It may be difficult to seal perforations larger than 3 cm. Such defects may be sealed with omentum or jejunal serosa from a Roux-en-Y type limb. 

Other options:

Billroth I and II are gastrectomy-based procedures where the gastric antrum is removed, hence reducing the acid. In Billroth I gastrectomy, the lower half of the stomach is removed, and the cut stomach is anastomosed to the first part of the duodenum. In Billroth II, two-thirds of the stomach is removed, the duodenal stump is closed and the stomach is anastomosed to the jejunum.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient has complaints of painless cervical lymphadenopathy with fever, malaise, and weight loss. A lymph node was biopsied and the findings are as shown below.  All are true about the condition except

choices.text: Involves single axial group of lymph nodes

questions.solution:
The lymph node shows classical Reed-Sternberg cell seen in Hodgkin lymphoma. Mesenteric nodes are infrequently involved in Hodgkin lymphoma.

Hodgkin lymphoma is a group of lymphoid neoplasms arising in a single node and spreads from the nodes to spleen, then the liver, and finally bone marrow.

The clinical importance of this predictable route of spread is highlighted by the importance of staging which determines prognosis as well the treatment of HL.

Contiguous spread Non-contiguous spread
Mesenteric nodes and Waldeyer ring rarely involved Commonly involved

questions.text: Siewert classification is used in
questions.solution:
• Siewert classification system is based on the anatomic location of adenocarcinoma which are in close proximity to the GE junction.
  • There are three Siewart types:
    • Type 1: Tumors of the distal esophagus, within 1-5 cm above the GE junction
    • Type 2: Tumor centre located from 1cm above the GE junction to 2cm below it.
    • Type 3: It is also called sub-cardinal and is located 2 to 5 cm below the GE junction.

questions.text: Enzyme defect in classical galactosemia is?
questions.solution:
Galactose 1 PO4 uridyl transferase deficiency leads to Classic galactosemia.

Classic galactosemia :

  • Galactose 1-phosphate uridyl transferase deficiency
  • Autosomal recessive disorder
  • Galactosemia and galactosuria seen
  • Accumulation of galactose 1-phosphate and galactitol in nerve, lens , liver, and kidney causes liver damage, intellectual disability, and cataracts
  • Prenatal diagnosis - chorionic villus sampling
  • Treatment is removal of galactose from diet

questions.text: Dofetilide acts on which of the following site in the given image?
questions.solution:
Dofetilide is a class III anti arrhythmic drug.

This newer antiarrhythmic prolongs APD and ERP by selectively blocking rapid component of delayed rectifier K+ current without affecting other channels or receptors; has no autonomic or peripheral actions. It is therefore labelled as pure class III antiarrhythmic.

Classification of antiarrythmic drugs:

Class Action Drug
I Membrane stabilizing agentIA: Moderately decrease in dv/dt of Phase 0IB: Little decrease in dv/dt of Phase 0IC: Marked decrease in dv/dt of Phase 0  Quinidine, Procainamide, DisopyramideLidocaine, MexiletinePropafenone, Flecainide
II Anti adrenergic agents Propranolol, Esmolol, Sotalol
III Agents widening AP Amiodarone, Dronedarone Dofetilide, Ibutilide
IV Calcium channel blockers Verapamil, Diltiazem

questions.text: Pettenkofer described the concept of:
questions.solution:
• Max Joseph von Pettenkofer of Munich described this theory as disease was caused by a multitude of factors.
  • Louis Pasteur advanced the germ theory of disease.
  • Aristotle described the spontaneous generation theory.
  • MacMahon and Pugh described the theory of web of causation.

questions.text: What is the most potent statin?
questions.solution:
• Among the statins, PITAVASTATIN is the latest and most potent statin. Use of pitavastatin along with gemfibrozil should be avoided as the latter decreases its clearance.
  • ROSUVASTATIN has the longest t1/2 among the statins.
